<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">







<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Indicate by check mark whether the registrants (1)&nbsp;have filed all reports required to be filed
by Section&nbsp;13 or </I><I>15(d)</I><I> of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 during the preceding 12&nbsp;months (or
for such shorter period that the registrants were required to file such reports), and (2)&nbsp;have been
subject to such filing requirements for the past 90&nbsp;days. Yes </I><FONT face="Wingdings">&#254;</FONT><I> No </I><FONT face="Wingdings">&#111;</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Indicate by check mark whether the registrant is a large accelerated filer, an accelerated
filer, or a non-accelerated filer. See definition of &#147;accelerated filer&#148; and &#147;large accelerated
filer&#148; in Rule&nbsp;12b-2 of the Exchange Act. (Check one):</I>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="15%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This combined Form 10-Q is separately filed by The Southern Company, Alabama Power Company,
Georgia Power Company, Gulf Power Company, Mississippi Power Company, and Southern Power Company.
Savannah Electric and Power Company was merged into Georgia Power Company on July&nbsp;1, 2006.
Savannah Electric and Power Company&#146;s separate Securities and Exchange Commission reporting
obligations were terminated following the merger. Georgia Power Company accounted for the merger
in a manner similar to a pooling of interests, and Georgia Power Company&#146;s financial statements
contained herein give effect to the merger as though it had occurred on January&nbsp;1, 2005.
Information contained herein relating to any individual registrant is filed by such registrant on
its own behalf. Each registrant makes no representation as to information relating to the other
registrants.

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>CAUTIONARY STATEMENT REGARDING FORWARD-LOOKING INFORMATION</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q contains forward-looking statements. Forward-looking
statements include, among other things, statements concerning the strategic goals for the wholesale
business, storm damage cost recovery and repairs, fuel cost recovery, environmental regulations and
expenditures, synthetic fuel investments, financing activities, completion of construction
projects, impacts of adoption of new accounting rules, access to sources of capital, and estimated
construction and other expenditures. In some cases, forward-looking statements can be identified by
terminology such as &#147;may,&#148; &#147;will,&#148; &#147;could,&#148; &#147;should,&#148; &#147;expects,&#148; &#147;plans,&#148; &#147;anticipates,&#148;
&#147;believes,&#148; &#147;estimates,&#148; &#147;projects,&#148; &#147;predicts,&#148; &#147;potential,&#148; or &#147;continue&#148; or the negative of
these terms or other similar terminology. There are various factors that could cause actual results
to differ materially from those suggested by the forward-looking statements; accordingly, there can
be no assurance that such indicated results will be realized. These factors include:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the impact of recent and future federal and state regulatory change, including legislative and
regulatory initiatives regarding deregulation and restructuring of the electric utility industry, implementation of
the Energy Policy Act of 2005, and also changes in environmental, tax, and other laws and regulations to which
Southern Company and its subsidiaries are subject, as well as changes in application of existing laws and
regulations;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>current and future litigation, regulatory investigations, proceedings, or inquiries, including the pending
EPA civil actions against certain Southern Company subsidiaries, FERC matters, IRS audits, and Mirant matters;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the effects, extent, and timing of the entry of additional competition in the markets in which Southern
Company&#146;s subsidiaries operate;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>variations in demand for electricity, including those relating to weather, the general economy and
population, and business growth (and declines);</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>available sources and costs of fuels;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>

    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>fluctuations in the level of oil prices;</TD>

    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the level of production, if any, by the synthetic fuel operations at Carbontronics Synfuels Investors LP
and Alabama Fuel Products, LLC for the remainder of fiscal year 2006 and fiscal year 2007;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>internal restructuring or other restructuring options that may be pursued;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>potential business strategies, including acquisitions or dispositions of assets or businesses, which cannot
be assured to be completed or beneficial to Southern Company or its subsidiaries;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the ability of counterparties of Southern Company and its subsidiaries to make payments as and when due;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the ability to obtain new short- and long-term contracts with neighboring utilities;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the direct or indirect effect on Southern Company&#146;s business resulting from terrorist incidents and the
threat of terrorist incidents;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>interest rate fluctuations and financial market conditions and the results of financing efforts, including
Southern Company&#146;s and its subsidiaries&#146; credit ratings;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the ability of Southern Company and its subsidiaries to obtain additional generating capacity at
competitive prices;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>catastrophic events such as fires, earthquakes, explosions, floods, hurricanes, or other similar
occurrences;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the direct or indirect effects on Southern Company&#146;s business resulting from incidents similar to the
August&nbsp;2003 power outage in the Northeast;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the effect of accounting pronouncements issued periodically by standard setting bodies; and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>other factors discussed elsewhere herein and in other reports filed by the registrants from time to time
with the SEC.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="108"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<br>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>



<DIV align="Center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">THIRD QUARTER 2006 vs. THIRD QUARTER 2005<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2006 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2005

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Discussion of the results of operations is focused on Southern Company&#146;s primary business of
electricity sales in the Southeast by the retail operating companies &#150; Alabama Power, Georgia
Power, Gulf Power, and Mississippi Power &#150; and Southern Power. Southern Power is an electric
wholesale generation subsidiary with market-based rate authority. Southern Company&#146;s other
business activities include investments in synthetic fuels and leveraged lease projects,
telecommunications, and energy-related services. For additional information on these businesses,
see BUSINESS &#150; The SOUTHERN System &#150; &#147;Retail Operating Companies,&#148; &#147;Southern Power,&#148; and &#147;Other
Business&#148; in Item&nbsp;1 of the Form 10-K. For information regarding the synthetic fuel investments,
see Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements under &#147;INCOME TAX MATTERS &#150; Synthetic Fuel Tax
Credits&#148; herein.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Hurricanes Dennis and Katrina hit Southern Company&#146;s service territory in July and August
2005, respectively. As a result of these storms, as well as Hurricane Ivan in September&nbsp;2004,
Southern Company has incurred significant restoration costs. In addition, fuel costs at each of the
retail operating companies rose significantly during 2005 and the first nine months of 2006.
Southern Company continues to make significant progress in working with its regulators to develop
methods to enable the timely recovery of these costs. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150;
FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;PSC Matters&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and FUTURE
EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and State PSC Matters&#148; and Notes (H), (I), and (K)&nbsp;to the Condensed
Financial Statements herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company continues to focus on several key performance indicators. These indicators
include customer satisfaction, plant availability, system reliability, and earnings per share. For
additional information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; OVERVIEW &#150;
&#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Earnings</B>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Company&#146;s third quarter 2006 earnings were $738.0&nbsp;million ($0.99 per share) compared with
$722.2&nbsp;million ($0.97 per share) for third quarter 2005. The increase in earnings for the third
quarter 2006 resulted primarily from higher revenues due to sustained economic strength and
customer growth in the Southern Company service area when compared to the same period in 2005. The
increase to earnings was partially offset by higher maintenance expense, reduced earnings
associated with synthetic fuel investments, and higher interest expense when compared to the same
period in 2005.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company&#146;s year-to-date 2006 earnings were $1.38&nbsp;billion ($1.86 per share) compared
with $1.43&nbsp;billion ($1.92 per share) for year-to-date 2005. The decrease in earnings year-to-date
2006 resulted primarily from higher other operations expense, higher maintenance expense, an
increase in depreciation and amortization, reduced earnings associated with synthetic fuel
investments, and higher interest expense when compared to year-to-date 2005. The decrease to
earnings was partially offset by an increase in revenues due to sustained economic strength,
customer growth, and warmer weather in the Southern Company service area when compared to
year-to-date 2005.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->13<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the following:
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Retail revenues</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, retail revenues increased by $181.1&nbsp;million when compared to third
quarter 2005. Excluding changes in revenues related to certain cost recovery mechanisms such as
fuel and storm damage which generally have no effect on net income, retail revenues increased $20
million in the third quarter of 2006 when compared to the same period in 2005. The primary driver
for this increase was a 2.3% increase in retail KWH sales. Weather-adjusted average consumption by
retail customers increased 2.4% when compared to the same period in 2005. The increase in retail
revenues was partially offset by a decrease in revenues associated with lower market-based rates to
large commercial and industrial customers.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, retail revenues increased by $799.0&nbsp;million when compared to the same
period in 2005. Excluding changes in fuel and other cost recovery mechanisms, retail revenues
increased $164&nbsp;million year-to-date 2006 when compared to the same period in 2005. The primary
driver for this increase was a 2.4% increase in retail KWH sales. Weather-adjusted average
consumption by retail customers increased 1.4% when compared to the same period in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Favorable weather and continued customer and demand growth from sustained economic strength in
the Southeast contributed to the third quarter and year-to-date 2006 increases in KWH sales. The
number of retail customers increased by 1.8% as of September&nbsp;2006 compared to September&nbsp;2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Details of retail revenues are as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Sales for resale</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, sales for resale were flat when compared to the same period in
2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, sales for resale increased $123.1&nbsp;million over the same period in 2005.
The year-to-date 2006 increase reflects a rise in fuel revenues due to a 16.6% increase in the
average unit cost of fuel per net KWH generated when compared to year-to-date 2005. New wholesale
contracts and additional revenue on existing wholesale contracts also contributed to the increase
over year-to-date 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Other electric revenues</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, other electric revenues increased $9.4&nbsp;million as a result of an
increase in rent from electric property of $2.9&nbsp;million, an increase in customer fees of $2.6
million, an increase in transmission revenues of $2.0&nbsp;million, and an increase in outdoor lighting
revenues of $1.9&nbsp;million when compared to the same period in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, other electric revenues increased $26.0&nbsp;million as a result of an
increase in transmission revenues of $13.4&nbsp;million, an increase in outdoor lighting revenues of
$4.9&nbsp;million, an increase in customer fees of $4.7&nbsp;million, and an increase in rent from electric
property of $3.3&nbsp;million when compared to year-to-date 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Transmission revenues are generally offset by related expenses and do not significantly affect
net income.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fuel expense and Purchased power expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fuel expense and purchased power expense increased $109.4&nbsp;million in the third quarter 2006
over the third quarter 2005 due to a $63.6&nbsp;million increase in the cost of fuel and a $45.8&nbsp;million
increase related to total KWHs generated and purchased.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fuel expense and purchased power expense increased $629.1&nbsp;million year-to-date 2006 over the
same period in 2005 due to a $519.5&nbsp;million increase in the cost
of fuel and a $109.6 million
increase related to total KWHs generated and purchased.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Increases in fuel expense at the retail operating companies are generally offset by fuel
revenues and do not affect net income. See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC and State PSC Matters
&#150; Retail Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; herein for additional information. Fuel expenses incurred under
Southern Power&#146;s PPAs are generally the responsibility of the counterparties and do not
significantly affect net income.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Other operations expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, other operations expense decreased $37.8&nbsp;million when compared with
the same period in 2005 primarily due to a decrease in administrative and general expense of $46.4
million as a result of lower salaries and wages expense and lower shared services expense, as well
as a $5.4&nbsp;million decrease in other production expense. The third quarter 2006 decrease was
partially offset by a $10.0&nbsp;million increase in transmission and distribution expense and an
increase in customer service and sales expense of $4.0&nbsp;million resulting primarily from technology
costs, promotional expenses for energy efficiency programs, and an increase in bad debt expense.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, other operations expense increased $24.0&nbsp;million when compared with the
same period in 2005 primarily due to a $25.6&nbsp;million increase in transmission and distribution
expense; an increase in customer service and sales expense of $19.7&nbsp;million resulting primarily
from technology costs, promotional expenses for energy efficiency programs, and an increase in bad
debt expense; and a $1.3&nbsp;million increase in other production expense. The year-to-date 2006
increase was partially offset by a $22.6&nbsp;million decrease in administrative and general expense.
The decrease in administrative and general expense was the result of lower salaries and wages
expense and lower shared services expense, partially offset by additional compensation related to
expensing of stock options, primarily in the first quarter of 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other production, transmission, and distribution expenses fluctuate from year to year due to
timing of plant outages and system maintenance projects as well as normal increases in costs.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Maintenance expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, maintenance expense increased $29.8&nbsp;million when compared to the
same period in 2005. The increase was primarily the result of a $24.0&nbsp;million increase in
transmission and distribution
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->15<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">expense, a $4.5&nbsp;million increase in other production expense, and a $1.3&nbsp;million increase in
administrative and general expense.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the first quarter of 2005, Alabama Power recorded $45&nbsp;million of expenses in accordance
with an accounting order approved by the Alabama PSC to offset the costs of Hurricane Ivan and
restore the natural disaster reserve. In accordance with the accounting order, Alabama Power also
returned certain regulatory liabilities related to deferred taxes to its retail customers;
therefore, the combined effects of this accounting order had no impact on net income. See Note 3
to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K for additional information. For year-to-date 2006, maintenance expense increased $32.7
million when compared to the same period in 2005. Excluding the impact of the $45&nbsp;million Alabama
Power accounting order, year-to-date 2006 maintenance expense increased $77.7&nbsp;million over the same
period in 2005. The increase was primarily the result of a $56.7&nbsp;million increase in transmission
and distribution expense, a $17.2&nbsp;million increase in other production expense, and a $3.8&nbsp;million
increase in administrative and general expense.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
production, transmission, and distribution expenses fluctuate from year to year due to
timing of plant outages and system maintenance projects as well as normal increases in costs.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Depreciation and amortization</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The third quarter
2006 increase in depreciation and amortization when compared to the third
quarter 2005 was not material.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date
2006, depreciation and amortization increased $20.7&nbsp;million when compared
with the same period in 2005. This increase is primarily the result of increases in depreciable
property, plant, and equipment, including Southern Power&#146;s Plants Oleander, DeSoto, and Rowan,
acquired in June&nbsp;2005, June&nbsp;2006, and September&nbsp;2006, respectively, as well as increases in
depreciation rates and changes in the estimated lives of depreciable assets. The year-to-date 2006
increase was partially offset by a decrease in amortization of the regulatory liability related to
additional Plant Daniel capacity at Mississippi Power and a decrease in amortization at Georgia
Power related to the inclusion of new certified PPAs in retail rates on a levelized basis over a
three-year period as ordered by the Georgia PSC under the terms of the retail rate order effective
January&nbsp;1, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Taxes other than income taxes</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The $7.6&nbsp;million
and $36.1&nbsp;million increases in taxes other than income taxes in the third
quarter and year-to-date 2006, respectively, when compared with the same periods in 2005 were
primarily due to increases in municipal franchise and gross receipts taxes associated with
increases in revenues from energy sales. An increase in property taxes associated with changes in
property tax rates, changes in the assessed value of properties, and increases in total property
value also contributed to the increases over third quarter and year-to-date 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Allowance for equity funds used during construction</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The third
quarter 2006 increase in allowance for equity funds used during construction when
compared to the third quarter 2005 was not material.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
year-to-date 2006, allowance for equity funds used during construction decreased $7.1
million when compared to the same period in 2005 primarily as a result of the completion of the
Plant McIntosh combined cycle units 10 and 11 by Georgia Power in June&nbsp;2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Equity in losses of unconsolidated subsidiaries</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company
has made investments in two synthetic fuel production facilities that
generate operating losses. These investments also allow Southern Company to claim federal income
tax credits that offset these operating losses and make the projects profitable. The $36.8&nbsp;million
and $44.6&nbsp;million decreases in equity in losses of unconsolidated subsidiaries in the third quarter
and year-to-date 2006, respectively, when compared with the same periods in 2005, were primarily a
result of terminating Southern Company&#146;s membership interest in one of the synthetic fuel entities
which reduced the amount of Southern Company&#146;s share of the losses and, therefore, the funding
obligation for the third quarter and year-to-date 2006. These decreases also resulted from lower
operating expenses while the production facilities at the other synthetic fuel entity were idled
from May to
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->16<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Impairment loss on equity method investments</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The third quarter
2006 increase in impairment loss on equity method investments when compared
to the third quarter 2005 was not material.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date
2006, impairment loss on equity method investments increased $16.0&nbsp;million
when compared with the same period in 2005. In June&nbsp;2006, Southern Company recorded a $15.3
million impairment associated with its investments in synthetic fuels. In May&nbsp;2006, production at
one of the synthetic fuel investments was idled due to a projected phase-out of tax credits because
of high oil prices. Effective July&nbsp;1, 2006, Southern Company terminated its membership interest in
the other synthetic fuel investment. Southern Company will not be entitled to any further tax
credits from this investment. As a result of these actions and the projected continued phase-out
of tax credits due to high oil prices, the investments in these two synthetic fuel entities were
considered fully impaired. See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Income Tax Matters &#150; Synthetic Fuel
Tax Credits&#148; and Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements under &#147;INCOME TAX MATTERS &#150;
Synthetic Fuel Tax Credits&#148; herein for further information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, interest charges and other financing costs increased $23.0&nbsp;million
when compared to the third quarter 2005 as a result of increases in notes payable and long-term
debt outstanding for the third quarter 2006, as well as an increase in average interest rates on
variable rate debt. Variable rates on pollution control bonds are highly correlated with the BMA
Municipal Swap Index, which averaged 3.6% in the third quarter 2006, compared to 2.4% in the third
quarter 2005. Variable rates on commercial paper and senior notes are highly correlated with the
one-month LIBOR, which averaged 5.3% in the third quarter 2006, compared to 3.6% in the third
quarter 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, interest charges and other financing costs increased $86.9&nbsp;million when
compared to the same period in 2005 as a result of increases in notes payable and long-term debt
outstanding for year-to-date 2006, as well as an increase in average interest rates on variable
rate debt. The BMA Municipal Swap Index averaged 3.4% year-to-date 2006, compared to 2.3%
year-to-date 2005. The one-month LIBOR averaged 5.0% year-to-date 2006, compared to 3.1%
year-to-date 2005. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150;
&#147;Financing Activities&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and herein for additional
information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Other income (expense), net</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, other income (expense), net decreased $36.2&nbsp;million when compared
to the same period in 2005 as a result of a $43.9&nbsp;million decrease related to changes in the value
of derivative transactions, partially offset by a $2.2&nbsp;million increase in miscellaneous income
items and a $6.7&nbsp;million decrease in miscellaneous income deductions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For the year-to-date 2006, other income (expense), net decreased $24.5&nbsp;million when compared
to the same period in 2005 as a result of a $35.8&nbsp;million decrease related to changes in the value
of derivative transactions, as well as Alabama Power&#146;s recognition of $5.0&nbsp;million associated with
the consent decree entered in the NSR litigation. See Note 3 to the financial statements of
Southern Company under &#147;Environmental Matters &#150; New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K and Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements under &#147;NEW SOURCE REVIEW ACTIONS &#150; New
Source Review Litigation&#148; herein for further information. These decreases were partially offset by
the release of $6.3&nbsp;million in certain obligations associated with Southern Company&#146;s synthetic
fuel investments which was terminated effective July&nbsp;1, 2006. See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150;
&#147;Income Tax Matters &#150; Synthetic Fuel Tax Credits&#148; and Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements under &#147;INCOME TAX MATTERS &#150; Synthetic Fuel Tax Credits&#148; herein for further information.

period in 2005 due to higher taxable earnings and a $51.6&nbsp;million decrease in synthetic fuel tax

oil prices in the third quarter of 2006.

discussed under &#147;Maintenance expense&#148; above.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Southern Company&#146;s
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous factors that affect
the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Southern Company&#146;s primary business of selling
electricity. These factors include the retail operating companies&#146; ability to maintain a stable
regulatory environment that continues to allow for the recovery of all prudently incurred costs.
Another major factor is the profitability of the competitive market-based wholesale generating
business and associated federal regulatory policy, which may impact Southern Company&#146;s level of
participation in this market. Future earnings for the electricity business in the near term will
depend, in part, upon growth in energy sales, which is subject to a number of factors. These
factors include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities, energy
conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and
the rate of economic growth in the service area. For additional information relating to these
issues, see RISK FACTORS in Item&nbsp;1A and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS
POTENTIAL of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be fully recovered in rates on a timely basis. As discussed in the
Form 10-K, environmental compliance spending over the next several years may exceed amounts
estimated. Some of the factors driving the anticipated increase are higher commodity costs, market
demand for labor, and scope additions and clarifications. The timing, specific requirements, and
estimated costs could also change as environmental regulations are modified. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Southern Company
in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Environmental Matters&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>New Source Review Litigation</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150; New
Source Review Actions&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of
Southern Company under &#147;Environmental Matters &#150; New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for additional information regarding a civil action brought by the EPA alleging that Alabama
Power had violated the NSR provisions of the Clean Air Act and related state laws with respect to
certain of its coal-fired generating facilities. On June&nbsp;19, 2006, the U.S. District Court for the
Northern District of Alabama entered a consent decree between Alabama Power and the EPA, resolving
alleged NSR violations at Plant Miller. The consent decree required Alabama Power to pay $100,000
to resolve the government&#146;s claim for a civil penalty and donate $4.9&nbsp;million of sulfur dioxide
emission allowances to a nonprofit charitable
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->18<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">organization. As a result, Alabama Power has recognized $5&nbsp;million in other income (expense), net
related to the consent decree. The consent decree also formalizes specific emissions reductions to
be accomplished by Alabama Power, consistent with other Clean Air Act programs that require
emissions reductions. On August&nbsp;14, 2006, the district court granted Alabama Power&#146;s motion for
summary judgment and entered a final judgment in favor of Alabama Power on the EPA&#146;s claims related
to Plants Barry, Gaston, Gorgas, and Greene County, based on the district court&#146;s previous ruling
regarding the correct legal tests and stipulations entered between the parties. The plaintiffs
have appealed this decision to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The final
resolution of these claims is dependent on these appeals and possible further court action and,
therefore, cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>New Source Review Reform Rules</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;17, 2006, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit vacated the EPA&#146;s
October&nbsp;2003 proposed rule which sought to clarify the scope of the existing Routine Maintenance,
Repair, and Replacement Exclusion. Because this rule was not yet in effect, the court&#146;s ruling is
not anticipated to have any impact on Southern Company or its subsidiaries. In September&nbsp;2006, the
EPA also proposed additional rules intended to clarify the test for determining when an emissions
increase subject to the NSR permitting requirements has occurred. The potential impact of these
proposed rules will depend on the adoption of final rules by the EPA. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150; New Source Review Actions&#148; of
Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fine Particulate Matter Regulations</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters -
Environmental Statutes and Regulations &#150; Air Quality&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form
10-K for additional information regarding nonattainment designations for the fine particulate
matter air quality standard. On September&nbsp;21, 2006, the EPA published a final rule lowering the
24-hour fine particulate matter standard even further and plans to designate nonattainment areas
based on the new standard by December&nbsp;2009. On September&nbsp;30, 2006, the EPA also published its
final rule for implementation of the existing fine particulate matter standard. State plans for
addressing the nonattainment designations under the existing standard are required by April&nbsp;2008
and could require further reductions in SO<SUB style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-bottom">2</SUB> and NOx emissions from power plants. The
final outcome of this matter cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;30, 2006, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit ruled in favor of Georgia
Power on its appeal and reversed the district court&#146;s order regarding certain alleged opacity
violations at Plant Wansley. The court of appeals remanded the case to the U.S. District Court for
the Northern District of Georgia for further proceedings consistent with its decision. The
ultimate outcome of this matter cannot now be determined. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS
- - FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150; Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation&#148; of
Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under
&#147;Environmental Matters &#150; Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Birmingham Area Eight-Hour Ozone Attainment Redesignation</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters -
Environmental Statutes and Regulations &#150; Air Quality&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form
10-K for additional information regarding nonattainment designations for the eight-hour ozone air
quality standard. On May&nbsp;12, 2006, the EPA published a final rule approving the State of Alabama&#146;s
request to
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">redesignate the Birmingham eight-hour ozone nonattainment area to attainment under the standard.
The EPA also approved a revision to the Alabama state implementation plan, containing a maintenance
plan to ensure the area&#146;s continued compliance with the standard and to address any future
exceedances of the standard. The EPA&#146;s redesignation determination became effective on June&nbsp;12,
2006.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FERC and State PSC Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC Matters &#150;
Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Southern Company under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for
measuring generation market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to
assess Southern Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory. Each of the
retail operating companies and Southern Power has authorization from the FERC to sell power to
non-affiliates, including short-term opportunity sales, at market-based prices. Specific FERC
approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based sale to an affiliate. On February&nbsp;15,
2005, Southern Company submitted additional information related to generation dominance in its
retail service territory. Any new market-based rate sales by any subsidiary of Southern Company
in its retail service territory entered into after February&nbsp;27, 2005 will be subject to refund
to the level of the default cost-based rates, pending the outcome of the proceeding. Such sales
through May&nbsp;27, 2006, the end of the 15-month refund period, were approximately $19.7&nbsp;million
for the Southern Company system. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures for
entities that are found to have market power are ultimately applied, the retail operating
companies and Southern Power may be required to charge cost-based rates for certain wholesale
sales in the Southern Company retail service territory, which may be lower than negotiated
market-based rates. The final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in which the final
methodology for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted
and cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated an investigation to determine whether Southern
Company satisfies the other three parts of the FERC&#146;s market-based rate analysis: transmission
market power, barriers to
entry, and affiliate abuse or reciprocal dealing. The FERC established a new 15-month refund
period related to this expanded investigation. Any new market-based rate sales involving any
Southern Company subsidiary will be subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders lower rates as
a result of this new investigation, with the refund period beginning July&nbsp;19, 2005. The impact of
all such sales through September&nbsp;30, 2006 is not expected to exceed $54.2&nbsp;million, of which $15.5
million relates to sales inside the retail service territory discussed above. The FERC also
directed that this expanded proceeding be held in abeyance pending the outcome of the proceeding on
the IIC discussed below. In its order in the IIC proceeding of October&nbsp;5, 2006, pertaining to
issues that overlap those in this proceeding, the FERC indicated that it would issue an order in
this expanded proceeding within 90&nbsp;days, seeking comment on the issues that may remain appropriate
for investigation as well as procedures for addressing those issues.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company and its subsidiaries believe that there is no meritorious basis for this
proceeding and are vigorously defending themselves in this matter. However, the final outcome of
this matter, including any remedies to be applied in the event of an adverse ruling in this
proceeding, cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated a new proceeding to examine (1)&nbsp;the provisions of the IIC
among Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, Savannah Electric, Southern
Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of which the power pool of Southern Company is
operated, and, in particular,
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->20<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">the propriety of the continued inclusion of Southern Power as a party to the IIC, (2)&nbsp;whether
any parties to the IIC have violated the FERC&#146;s standards of conduct applicable to utility
companies that are transmission providers, and (3)&nbsp;whether Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct
defining Southern Power as a &#147;system company&#148; rather than a &#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just and
reasonable. In connection with the formation of Southern Power, the FERC authorized Southern
Power&#146;s inclusion in the IIC in 2000. The FERC also previously approved Southern Company&#146;s code
of conduct. The FERC order directs that the ALJ who
presided over a proceeding involving approval of PPAs between Southern Power and Georgia Power
and Savannah Electric be assigned to preside over the hearing in this proceeding and that the
testimony and exhibits presented in that proceeding be preserved to the extent appropriate.
Effective July&nbsp;19, 2005, revenues from transactions under the IIC involving any Southern Company
subsidiaries will be subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders any changes to the IIC.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;11, 2006, Southern Company, Calpine Corporation, Coral Energy, and Dalton
Utilities filed a settlement offer that would resolve the proceeding, and does not require any
refunds. The ALJ certified the settlement to the FERC, which on October&nbsp;5, 2006 issued an order
accepting the settlement subject to Southern Company&#146;s agreement to accept certain modifications
to its terms. On October&nbsp;20, 2006, Southern Company notified the FERC that it accepted the
modifications. The modifications largely involve functional separation and information
restrictions related to marketing activities conducted on behalf of Southern Power. Southern
Company filed with the FERC on November&nbsp;6, 2006 an implementation plan to comply with
the modifications set forth in the order. The impact of the modifications is currently being
assessed but is not expected to be material. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Intercompany Interchange
Contract&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern
Company under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Intercompany Interchange Contract&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Retail Fuel Cost Recovery</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The retail operating companies each have established fuel cost recovery rates approved by their
respective state PSCs. In 2005 and the first nine months of 2006, the retail operating companies
have experienced higher than expected fuel costs for coal and gas. These higher fuel costs have
increased the under recovered fuel costs included in the balance sheets to approximately $1.4
billion at September&nbsp;30, 2006. Operating revenues are adjusted for differences in actual
recoverable fuel costs and amounts billed in current regulated rates. Accordingly, changes to the
billing factors will have no significant effect on Southern Company&#146;s revenues or net income but
will affect cash flow. The retail operating companies will continue to monitor the under recovered
fuel cost balance in light of these higher fuel costs. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150;
FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;PSC Matters &#150; Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and
Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Alabama Power Retail Regulatory
Matters&#148; and &#147;Georgia Power Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional
information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In March&nbsp;2006, Georgia Power and Savannah Electric filed a combined request for fuel cost
recovery rate changes with the Georgia PSC to be effective July&nbsp;1, 2006, the effective date of the
merger of Savannah Electric into Georgia Power. On June&nbsp;15, 2006, the Georgia PSC ruled on the
request and approved an increase in Georgia Power&#146;s total annual fuel billings of approximately
$400&nbsp;million. The Georgia PSC order provided for a combined ongoing fuel forecast but reduced the
requested increase related to such forecast by $200&nbsp;million. The Georgia PSC order included no
disallowances of previously incurred fuel costs. Estimated under recovered fuel costs are to be
recovered over 35&nbsp;months ending May&nbsp;2009 for customers in the former Georgia Power territory and
over 41&nbsp;months ending November&nbsp;2009 for customers in the former Savannah Electric territory. The
order also required Georgia Power to file for a new fuel cost recovery rate on a semi-annual basis,
beginning in September&nbsp;2006. Accordingly, on September&nbsp;15, 2006, Georgia Power filed a request to
recover fuel costs incurred through August&nbsp;2006 by increasing the fuel cost recovery rate. In
October&nbsp;2006, Georgia
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->21<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<P><HR noshade><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Power agreed with the Georgia PSC to file a supplementary request, by November&nbsp;13, 2006, reflecting
a forecast of annual fuel costs, as well as updated information for previously incurred fuel costs.
The Georgia PSC is scheduled to rule on the entire request in February&nbsp;2007, with the new rates to
become effective on March&nbsp;1, 2007. As of September&nbsp;30, 2006, Georgia Power had an under recovered
fuel balance of approximately $952&nbsp;million, of which $762&nbsp;million is currently included in the fuel
cost recovery rate. See Note (H)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional
information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Storm Damage Cost Recovery</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In July&nbsp;2005 and August&nbsp;2005, Hurricanes Dennis and Katrina, respectively, hit the Gulf Coast of
the United States and caused significant damage within Southern Company&#146;s service area, including
portions of the service areas of Gulf Power, Alabama Power, and Mississippi Power. In addition,
Hurricane Ivan hit the Gulf coast of Florida and Alabama in September&nbsp;2004, causing significant
damage to the service areas of both Gulf Power and Alabama Power. Each retail operating company
maintains a reserve to cover the cost of damages from major storms to its transmission and
distribution lines and the cost of uninsured damages to its generation facilities and other
property. In addition, each of the affected retail operating companies has been authorized by its
state PSC to defer the portion of the hurricane restoration costs that exceeded the balance in its
storm damage reserve account. As of September&nbsp;30, 2006, the deficit balance in Southern Company&#146;s
storm damage reserve accounts totaled approximately $367&nbsp;million, of which approximately $59
million and $308&nbsp;million, respectively, are included in the Condensed Balance Sheets herein under
&#147;Other Current Assets&#148; and &#147;Other Regulatory Assets.&#148; See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150;
FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;PSC Matters &#150; Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148; of Southern Company in Item
7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148; in
Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2006, the Mississippi PSC issued an order based upon a stipulation between Mississippi
Power and the Mississippi Public Utilities Staff. The stipulation and the associated order
certified actual storm restoration costs relating to Hurricane Katrina through April&nbsp;30, 2006 of
$267.9&nbsp;million and affirmed estimated additional costs through December&nbsp;31, 2007 of $34.5&nbsp;million,
for total storm restoration costs of $302.4&nbsp;million, without offset for the property damage reserve
of $3.0&nbsp;million. Of the total amount, $292.8&nbsp;million applies to Mississippi Power&#146;s retail
jurisdiction. The order directed Mississippi Power to file an application with the Mississippi
Development Authority (MDA)&nbsp;for Community Development Block Grants (CDBG). All CDBG proceeds received by Mississippi Power will be applied to both
retail and wholesale storm restoration costs and will be used to significantly mitigate the impacts
of the cost of storm restoration on Mississippi Power&#146;s customers. The retail portion of any
certified restoration costs not covered by the CDBG program are expected to be funded through the
state bond program previously approved by the State of Mississippi legislature. The Mississippi
PSC order also indicated that the state bond program would be appropriate funding for all or a
portion of a new storm operations center if approved and for an appropriate storm reserve, both of
which require additional Mississippi PSC action. If state bonds are used for any portion of the
Hurricane Katrina restoration costs, periodic true-up mechanisms will be structured to comply with
terms and requirements from the legislation. Mississippi Power filed the CDBG application with the
MDA in September&nbsp;2006. On October&nbsp;30, 2006, Mississippi Power received from the MDA a CDBG in the
amount of $276.4&nbsp;million. Mississippi Power filed an application for a financing order with the
Mississippi PSC on July&nbsp;3, 2006 for restoration costs under the state bond program, including the
property damage reserve funding and the construction of the storm operations center. On October
27, 2006, the Mississippi PSC issued a financing order that authorizes the issuance of $121.2
million of system restoration bonds. This amount includes $25.2&nbsp;million for the retail storm
recovery costs not covered by the CDBG, $60&nbsp;million for a property damage reserve, and $36&nbsp;million
for the retail portion of the construction of the storm operations facility. The bonds will be
issued by the Mississippi State Bond Commission and will represent an obligation of the State of
Mississippi. The final outcome of this matter cannot now be
determined. See Note (I)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional
information.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->22<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July&nbsp;2006, the Florida PSC issued its order approving a stipulation and settlement between
Gulf Power and several consumer groups that resolved all matters relating to Gulf Power&#146;s request
for recovery of incurred costs for storm-recovery activities, the replenishment of Gulf Power&#146;s
property damage reserve, and the related request for permission to issue $87.2&nbsp;million in
securitized storm-recovery bonds. The order provides for an extension of the storm-recovery
surcharge currently being collected by Gulf Power for an additional 27&nbsp;months, expiring in June
2009, in lieu of the requested issuance of storm-recovery bonds. According to the stipulation, the
funds resulting from the extension of the current surcharge will first be credited to the
unrecovered balance of storm-recovery costs associated with Hurricane Ivan until these costs have
been fully recovered. The funds will then be credited to the property reserve for recovery of the
storm-recovery costs of $52.6&nbsp;million associated with Hurricanes Dennis and Katrina that were
previously charged to the reserve. Should revenues collected by Gulf Power through the extension
of the storm-recovery surcharge exceed the storm-recovery costs associated with Hurricanes Dennis
and Katrina, the excess revenues will be credited to the reserve. See Note (K)&nbsp;to the Condensed
Financial Statements herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Mirant Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mirant was an energy company with businesses that included independent power projects and energy
trading and risk management companies in the U.S. and selected other countries. It was a
wholly-owned subsidiary of Southern Company until its initial public offering in October&nbsp;2000. In
April&nbsp;2001, Southern Company completed a spin-off to its shareholders of its remaining ownership,
and Mirant became an independent corporate entity. In July&nbsp;2003, Mirant filed for voluntary
reorganization under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the Bankruptcy Code. See Note 3 to the financial statements of
Southern Company under &#147;Mirant Matters &#150; Mirant Bankruptcy&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
information regarding Southern Company&#146;s contingent liabilities associated with Mirant, including guarantees of contractual commitments, litigation, and joint and
several liabilities in connection with the consolidated federal income tax return.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Mirant Bankruptcy Litigation</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Mirant Matters &#150; Mirant
Bankruptcy Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding the complaint filed in
June&nbsp;2005 against Southern Company alleging fraudulent activities and payments of illegal dividends
prior to the spin-off. In May&nbsp;2006, Southern Company filed a motion for summary judgment on all
claims in the case. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Mirant Securities Litigation</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Mirant Matters &#150; Mirant
Securities Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding a class action lawsuit
that several Mirant shareholders (plaintiffs)&nbsp;originally filed against Mirant and certain Mirant
officers in May&nbsp;2002. In November&nbsp;2002, Southern Company, certain former and current senior
officers of Southern Company, and 12 underwriters of Mirant&#146;s initial public offering were added as
defendants. On March&nbsp;24, 2006, the plaintiffs filed a Motion for Reconsideration requesting that
the court vacate that portion of its July&nbsp;14, 2003 order dismissing the plaintiffs&#146; claims based
upon Mirant&#146;s alleged improper energy trading and marketing activities involving the California
energy market. Southern Company and the other defendants have opposed the plaintiffs&#146; motion. The
plaintiffs have also stated that they intend to request that the court grant leave for them to
amend the complaint to add allegations based upon claims asserted against Southern Company in the
Mirant bankruptcy litigation. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under
&#147;Mirant Matters &#150; Mirant Bankruptcy Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional
information. The ultimate outcome of these matters cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>

</DIV>
