<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Southern Company Employee Savings Plan Litigation</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Mirant Matters &#150; Southern Company
Employee Savings Plan Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information related to the class
action complaint filed under ERISA in June&nbsp;2004, and amended in December&nbsp;2004 and November&nbsp;2005, on
behalf of a purported class of participants in or beneficiaries of The Southern Company Employee
Savings Plan at any time since April&nbsp;2, 2001 and whose plan accounts included investments in Mirant
common stock. In April&nbsp;2006, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia granted
summary judgment in favor of Southern Company and all individually named defendants in the case.
The plaintiff has filed an appeal of the ruling. The final outcome of this matter cannot be
determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Income Tax Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Leveraged Lease Transactions</I>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Income Tax Matters -
Leveraged Lease Transactions&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements
of Southern Company under &#147;Income Tax Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (B)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements under &#147;INCOME TAX MATTERS &#150; Leveraged Lease Transactions&#148; herein for
information regarding IRS challenges to Southern Company&#146;s transactions related to international
leveraged leases that could have material impacts on Southern Company&#146;s financial statements. In
July&nbsp;2006, the FASB released new guidance for the accounting for both leveraged leases and
uncertain tax positions that will be effective beginning in 2007. For the lease-in-lease-out
(LILO)&nbsp;transaction settled with the IRS in February&nbsp;2005, the new standard for leveraged leases
will require Southern Company to change the timing of income recognized under the lease, including
a cumulative effect upon adoption of the change. Southern Company estimates such cumulative effect
will reduce Southern Company&#146;s retained earnings by approximately $17&nbsp;million. The impact of these
proposed changes related to the sale-in-lease-out (SILO)&nbsp;transactions would be dependent on the
outcome of pending litigation, but could be significant, and potentially material, to Southern
Company&#146;s net income. Southern Company believes these transactions are valid leases for U.S. tax
purposes and the related deductions are allowable.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, Southern Company paid the full amount of the disputed tax and the
applicable interest on the SILO issue for tax years 2000-2001 and has filed a claim for refund.
The disputed tax amount is $79&nbsp;million and the related interest is approximately $24&nbsp;million for
these tax years. Southern Company has accounted for this payment as a deposit. This payment,
along with the anticipated disallowance of the claim, will close the issue with the IRS and
Southern Company plans to then proceed to litigate this matter. The IRS has also raised the SILO
and related penalty issues for tax years 2002 and 2003. The estimated amount of disputed tax and
interest for these years is approximately $90&nbsp;million and $17&nbsp;million, respectively, along with a
related penalty of approximately $9&nbsp;million. A current liability of $107&nbsp;million was recorded in
the third quarter 2006 to reflect the probable payment of tax and interest for these tax years to
the IRS in the fourth quarter 2006. Southern Company believes these transactions are valid leases
for U.S. tax purposes and will continue to defend this position through administrative appeals or
litigation. The ultimate outcome of these matters cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Synthetic Fuel Tax Credits</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As discussed in MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Income Tax
Matters &#150; Synthetic Fuel Tax Credits&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K, Southern
Company has made investments in two entities that produce synthetic fuel and receive tax credits
under Section&nbsp;45K (formerly Section&nbsp;29) of the IRC. In accordance with Section&nbsp;45K of the IRC,
these tax credits are subject to limitation as the annual average price of oil (as determined by
the DOE) increases over a specified, inflation-
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->24<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">adjusted dollar amount published in the spring of the subsequent year. Southern Company, along
with its partners in these investments, has continued to monitor oil prices. Reserves against
these tax credits of $27&nbsp;million have been recorded in the first nine months of 2006 due to
projected phase-outs of the credits in 2006 as a result of current and projected future oil prices.
See Note (J)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information regarding the
impact of these reserves on the effective tax rate.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In May&nbsp;2006, production at one of the synthetic fuel investments was idled due to continued
uncertainty over the value of tax credits. In addition, Southern Company entered into an agreement
in June&nbsp;2006 which terminated its ownership interest in its other synthetic fuel investment,
effective July&nbsp;1, 2006. In the first nine months of 2006, Southern Company entered into derivative
transactions designed to reduce its exposure to changes in the value of tax credits associated with
its synthetic fuel investments. These derivative transactions will be marked to market over the
remainder of the year through other income (expense), net. As a result of these actions and the
projected continued phase out of tax credits because of high oil prices, the investments in these
two synthetic fuel entities were considered fully impaired and approximately $16&nbsp;million was
written off and is reflected in the line item &#147;Impairment loss on equity method investments&#148; on
Southern Company&#146;s income statement herein. In September&nbsp;2006, due to reduced oil prices in the
third quarter, production was restarted at the synthetic fuel facility in which Southern Company
still has an ownership interest. In October&nbsp;2006, Southern Company entered into additional
derivative transactions to reduce its exposure to the potential phase-out of these income tax
credits in 2007. See Note (F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional
information regarding the impact of these derivatives. The final outcome of these matters cannot
now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Plant Franklin Construction
Project&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on the suspension of construction activities.
On May&nbsp;6, 2006, Southern Power signed a PPA with Progress Ventures, Inc. for 621 MW of capacity
from Plant Franklin. The PPA term is from 2009 through 2015. To provide this capacity, Southern
Power expects to complete construction of Franklin Unit 3 at a total cost of approximately $351
million, of which $176&nbsp;million had been spent as of September&nbsp;30, 2006. Construction is expected
to be complete in 2008.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective June&nbsp;1, 2006, Southern Power acquired all of the outstanding membership interests of
DeSoto County Generating Company, LLC (DeSoto) from Progress Genco Ventures LLC, a subsidiary of
Progress Energy, Inc. The results of DeSoto&#146;s operations have been included in Southern Power&#146;s
consolidated financial statements since that date. Southern Power&#146;s acquisition of the membership
interests in DeSoto was pursuant to an agreement dated May&nbsp;8, 2006 for an aggregate purchase price
of $79.2&nbsp;million. DeSoto owns a dual-fired generating plant near Arcadia, Florida with a nameplate
capacity of 340 MW. The plant&#146;s capacity and associated energy is sold under PPAs with Florida
Power &#038; Light Company that expire in 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective September&nbsp;1, 2006, Southern Power also acquired all of the outstanding membership
interests of Rowan County Power, LLC (Rowan) from the same subsidiary of Progress Energy, Inc.
Rowan owns a dual-fired generating plant near Salisbury, North Carolina with a nameplate capacity
of 985 MW. The purchase price was $328.8&nbsp;million. Substantially all of the plant&#146;s capacity and
associated energy is sold under PPAs with Duke Power, Energy United Electric Membership
Corporation, and North Carolina Municipal Power Agency No.&nbsp;1 that expire at various times through
2025.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;16, 2006, a subsidiary of Southern Company entered into a development agreement with
Duke Energy Corporation (Duke) to evaluate the potential construction of a new two-unit nuclear
plant at a jointly owned site in Cherokee County, South Carolina. If constructed, Southern Company
would own an interest in Unit 1, representing approximately 500 MW. Duke will be the developer and
licensed operator of any plant built at the site.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->25<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course
of business. In addition, Southern Company&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive
governmental regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over
environmental issues and claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, and
citizen enforcement of environmental requirements such as opacity and other air quality standards,
has increased generally throughout the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for
damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The ultimate
outcome of such pending or potential litigation against Southern Company and its subsidiaries
cannot be predicted at this time; however, for current proceedings not specifically reported herein
or in Note 3 to the
financial statements of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K, management does not anticipate
that the liabilities, if any, arising from such current proceedings would have a material adverse
effect on Southern Company&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various other
contingencies, regulatory matters, and other matters being litigated which may affect future
earnings potential.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Company prepares its consolidated financial statements in accordance with accounting
principles generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are
described in Note 1 to the financial statements of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K.
In the application of these policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact
on Southern Company&#146;s results of operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and
measurements could produce estimates that are significantly different from those recorded in the
financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; ACCOUNTING POLICIES -
&#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the
Form 10-K for a complete discussion of Southern Company&#146;s critical accounting policies and
estimates related to Electric Utility Regulation, Contingent Obligations, and Unbilled Revenues.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Stock Options</I>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On January&nbsp;1, 2006, Southern Company adopted FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123(R), &#147;Share-Based Payment,&#148;
using the modified prospective method. This statement requires that compensation cost relating to
share-based payment transactions be recognized in the financial statements. That cost will be
measured based on the grant date fair value of the equity or liability instruments issued. Although
the compensation expense required under the revised statement differs slightly, the impacts on
Southern Company&#146;s financial statements are similar to the pro forma disclosures previously
included in Note 1 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Stock Options&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K and in Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Income Taxes</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In July&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued Interpretation No.&nbsp;48 (FIN 48), &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income
Taxes.&#148; This interpretation requires that tax benefits must be &#147;more likely than not&#148; of being
sustained in order to be recognized. The provisions of FIN 48 must be applied to all tax positions
beginning January&nbsp;1, 2007. Southern Company is currently assessing the impact of FIN 48. The
impact on Southern Company&#146;s financial statements has not yet been determined.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->26<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Leveraged Leases</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also in July&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position No.&nbsp;FAS 13-2 (FSP 13-2), &#147;Accounting for a
Change or Projected Change in the Timing of Cash Flows Relating to Income Taxes Generated by a
Leveraged Lease Transaction.&#148; This staff position amends SFAS No.&nbsp;13, &#147;Accounting for Leases&#148; to
require recalculation of the rate of return and the allocation of income whenever the projected
timing of the income tax cash flows generated by a leveraged lease is revised. Southern Company
plans to adopt FSP 13-2 on January&nbsp;1, 2007. This adoption will require Southern Company to
recognize a cumulative effect of a $17&nbsp;million decrease to retained earnings as of January&nbsp;1, 2007 related to
the LILO transaction settled with the IRS in February&nbsp;2005. See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL -
&#147;Income Tax Matters &#150; Leveraged Lease Transactions&#148; above and Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements under &#147;INCOME TAX MATTERS &#150; Leveraged Lease Transactions&#148; herein for further details
about the effect of FSP 13-2.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fair Value Measurement</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;157 (SFAS No.&nbsp;157), &#147;Fair Value Measurements&#148; in September&nbsp;2006.
This standard provides guidance on how to measure fair value where it is permitted or required
under other accounting pronouncements. SFAS No.&nbsp;157 also requires additional disclosures about
fair value measurements. Southern Company will adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;157 on January&nbsp;1, 2008 and is
currently assessing the impact of this standard.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Pensions and Other Postretirement Plans</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;158 (SFAS No.&nbsp;158), &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting for Defined Benefit
Pension and Other Postretirement Plans &#150; an amendment of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;87, 88, 106, and
132(R)&#148; in September&nbsp;2006. This standard requires companies to fully recognize, as an asset or
liability, the overfunded or underfunded status of its benefits plans on the balance sheet.
Southern Company will adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;158 with a prospective application as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and
is currently assessing the requirements under this standard. The impact on Southern Company&#146;s
balance sheet has not yet been determined. SFAS No.&nbsp;158 also requires employers to measure the
funded status of plan assets and obligations as of the year-end balance sheet date. The new
measurement date requirement is effective for Southern Company as of December&nbsp;31, 2008 and will
require recognition of the net periodic benefit cost for the three-month transition period between
September&nbsp;30 and December&nbsp;31, 2007 through retained earnings as of January&nbsp;1, 2008.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Guidance on Considering the Materiality of Misstatements</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In September&nbsp;2006, the SEC issued Staff Accounting Bulletin No.&nbsp;108 (SAB 108), &#147;Considering the
Effects of Prior Year Misstatements when Quantifying Misstatements in Current Year Financial
Statements.&#148; SAB 108 addresses how the effects of prior year uncorrected misstatements should be
considered when quantifying misstatements in current year financial statements. SAB 108 requires
companies to quantify misstatements using both a balance sheet and an income statement approach and
to evaluate whether either approach results in quantifying an error that is material in light of
relevant quantitative and qualitative factors. When the effect of initial adoption is material,
companies will record the effect as a cumulative effect adjustment to beginning of year retained
earnings. The provisions of SAB 108 are effective for the Southern Company for the year ending
December&nbsp;31, 2006. The adoption of SAB 108 is not expected to have a material impact on Southern
Company&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->27<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Overview</B>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Net cash provided from operating activities totaled $2.0&nbsp;billion for first nine months of 2006,
compared to $2.1&nbsp;billion for the corresponding period in 2005. The $100&nbsp;million decrease is
primarily due to increases in fuel and storm damage costs and discontinued operations associated
with the sale of Southern Company Gas assets. For additional information regarding the sale of
Southern Company Gas assets, see Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein under
&#147;SOUTHERN COMPANY GAS SALE.&#148; Gross property additions to utility plant were $2.2&nbsp;billion in the
first nine months of 2006.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant balance sheet changes for the first nine months of the year include a $789&nbsp;million
increase in notes payable used primarily for plant acquisitions, construction expenditures, and
general corporate purposes. Property, plant, and equipment increased $1.1&nbsp;billion during the first
nine months of 2006 primarily from the DeSoto and Rowan plant acquisitions, the purchase and
installation of environmental equipment, and transmission and distribution construction. See Note
(L)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information on the DeSoto and Rowan
acquisitions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The market price of Southern Company&#146;s common stock at September&nbsp;30, 2006 was $34.46 per share
(based on the closing price as reported on the New York Stock Exchange) and the book value was
$15.20 per share, representing a market-to-book ratio of 227%, compared to $34.53, $14.42, and
240%, respectively, at the end of 2005. The dividend for the third quarter 2006 was $0.3875 per
share compared to $0.3725 per share in the third quarter 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company, the retail operating companies, Southern Power, and SCS have each maintained
investment grade ratings from the major rating agencies.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Southern Company&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program and other
funding requirements associated with scheduled maturities of long-term debt, as well as the related
interest, preferred and preference stock dividends, leases, trust funding requirements, and other
purchase commitments. Approximately $1.3&nbsp;billion will be required by September&nbsp;30, 2007 for
redemptions and maturities of long-term debt.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Company intends to meet its future capital needs through internal cash flow and external
security issuances. Equity capital can be provided from any combination of Southern Company&#146;s stock
plans, private placements, or public offerings. The amounts and timing of additional equity
capital to be raised will be contingent on Southern Company&#146;s investment opportunities. The retail
operating companies and Southern Power plan to obtain the funds required for construction and other
purposes from sources similar to those used in the past, primarily operating cash flows, with
capital contributions from Southern Company, short-term debt, and external security issuances
providing additional funds. However, the amount, type, and timing of any financings, if needed,
will depend upon maintenance of adequate earnings, prevailing market conditions, regulatory
approval, and other factors. Mississippi Power is considering other sources of funding for
storm-recovery costs. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY
&#150; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->28<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company&#146;s current liabilities frequently exceed current assets because of the
continued use of short-term debt as a funding source to meet cash needs as well as scheduled
maturities of long-term debt. To meet short-term cash needs and contingencies, the Southern
Company system had at September&nbsp;30, 2006 approximately $418&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents
and approximately $3.4&nbsp;billion of unused credit arrangements with banks, of which $131&nbsp;million
expire in 2006 and $3.3&nbsp;billion expire in 2007 and beyond. Of the facilities maturing in 2006, $50
million contain provisions allowing one-year term loans executable at the expiration date and $73
million contain provisions allowing two-year term loans executable at the expiration date. These
unused credit arrangements also provide liquidity support to variable rate pollution control bonds
and commercial paper programs. Southern Company expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed,
prior to expiration. See Note 6 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Bank Credit
Arrangements&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information. The retail operating
companies may also meet short-term cash needs through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to
issue and sell commercial paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and for the benefit
of each of the retail operating companies. At September&nbsp;30, 2006, the Southern Company system had
outstanding commercial paper of $1.8&nbsp;billion, bank notes of $250&nbsp;million, and extendible commercial
notes of $28.3&nbsp;million. Management believes that the need for working capital can be adequately met
by utilizing commercial paper programs and lines of credit without maintaining large cash balances.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Off-Balance Sheet
Financing Arrangements&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 7 to the financial statements of
Southern Company under &#147;Operating Leases&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information related to
Mississippi Power&#146;s lease of a combined cycle generating facility at Plant Daniel.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Company does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in
payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain
contracts that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of a credit
rating change to BBB and Baa2, or BBB- or
Baa3 or below. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity purchases and sales. At
September&nbsp;30, 2006, the maximum potential collateral requirements at a BBB and Baa2 rating were
approximately $9&nbsp;million and at a BBB- or Baa3 rating were approximately $258&nbsp;million. The maximum
potential collateral requirements at a rating below BBB- or Baa3 were approximately $716
million. In addition, through the acquisition of  Plant Rowan, Southern Power assumed a PPA
with Duke Power Company LLC that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the
event of a credit rating change to below BBB- or Baa3. The amount of collateral required would
depend upon actual losses, if any, resulting from a credit downgrade, limited to Southern Power&#146;s
remaining obligations under the contract. See Note (L)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements
herein for additional information regarding the acquisition. Generally, collateral may be provided
by a
Southern Company guaranty, letter of credit, or cash. Southern Company&#146;s operating subsidiaries
are also party to certain derivative agreements that could require collateral and/or accelerated
payment in the event of a credit rating change to below investment grade for Alabama Power and/or
Georgia Power. These agreements are primarily for natural gas price risk management activities. At
September&nbsp;30, 2006, Southern Company&#146;s total exposure to these types of agreements was
approximately $25&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Company&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed
materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2005 reporting period. In addition, Southern Company is
not aware of any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near
term.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, the retail operating companies have limited exposure to
market volatility in interest rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. In
addition, Southern Power&#146;s exposure to market volatility in commodity fuel prices and prices of
electricity is limited because its long-
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->29<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">term sales contracts shift substantially all fuel cost responsibility to the purchaser. To
mitigate residual risks relative to movements in electricity prices, the retail operating
companies and Southern Power enter into physical fixed-price contracts for the purchase and sale
of electricity through the wholesale electricity market and, to a lesser extent, into financial
hedge contracts for natural gas purchases. The retail operating companies have implemented
fuel-hedging programs at the instruction of their respective state PSCs.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unrealized gains and losses from mark-to-market adjustments on derivative contracts related to
the retail operating companies&#146; fuel hedging programs are recorded as regulatory assets and
liabilities. Realized gains and losses from these programs are included in fuel expense and are
recovered through the retail operating companies&#146; fuel cost recovery clauses. In addition,
unrealized gains and losses on energy-related derivatives used by Southern Power to hedge
anticipated purchases and sales are deferred in other comprehensive income. Gains and losses on
derivative contracts that are not designated as hedges are recognized in the income statement as
incurred. At September&nbsp;30, 2006, the fair value gain / (loss)&nbsp;of derivative energy contracts was
reflected in the financial statements as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Company also has exposure to changes in the value of Section&nbsp;45K tax credits
associated with its synthetic fuel investments arising from changes in the annual average price of
oil (as determined by the DOE). To mitigate certain of the risks relative to movements in oil
prices, Southern Company has entered into financial hedge contracts for oil. The fair value of
these actively quoted derivative oil contracts at September&nbsp;30, 2006
</DIV>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>THE SOUTHERN COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">was a $20.8&nbsp;million net liability,
and the contracts are expected to settle at the end of 2006. Changes in the
fair value of these contracts are currently being recognized in income and, over time, should
substantially offset the changes in value of the tax credits.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information,
see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Southern Company in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial
statements of Southern Company under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note
(F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the first nine months of 2006, Southern
Company and its subsidiaries issued $950&nbsp;million of
senior notes and $125.8&nbsp;million of obligations related to pollution control revenue bonds, settled
$630&nbsp;million notional amount of related interest rate hedges at a gain of $20&nbsp;million, and issued
$31&nbsp;million of common stock, including treasury stock, through employee and director stock plans.
The proceeds were primarily used to refund senior notes and pollution control revenue bonds and to
fund ongoing construction projects. The remainder was used to repay short-term indebtedness.
Approximately $18&nbsp;million of the hedge gain will be deferred in other comprehensive income and
amortized to income over a 10-year period. The remaining $2&nbsp;million related to a discontinued
hedge and was recognized immediately in income through interest expense. See Southern Company&#146;s
Condensed Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows herein for further details on financing activities
during the first nine months of 2006.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the first nine months of 2006, Southern Company and its subsidiaries entered into
derivative transactions designed to hedge interest rate risk of future debt issuances. The total
notional amount of these derivatives was $855&nbsp;million. See Note (F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for further details.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements and
contractual obligations, Southern Company and its subsidiaries plan to continue, when economically
feasible, a program to retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost
capital if market conditions permit.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->31<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Item&nbsp;3. Quantitative And Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk.</B>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148;
herein for each registrant, Notes 1 and 6 to the financial statements of Southern Company, Alabama
Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, and Mississippi Power and Notes 1 and 5 to the financial
statements of Southern Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. Also, see
Note (F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for information relating to derivative
instruments.

<DIV align="left">
<A name="141"></A>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Item&nbsp;4. Controls and Procedures.</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;Evaluation of disclosure controls and procedures.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of the end of the period covered by this quarterly report, Southern Company, Alabama Power,
Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, and Southern Power conducted separate evaluations
under the supervision and with the participation of each company&#146;s management, including the Chief
Executive Officer and the Chief Financial Officer, of the effectiveness of the design and operation
of the disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Sections&nbsp;13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) of the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934). Based upon these evaluations, the Chief Executive Officer and
the Chief Financial Officer, in each case, concluded that the disclosure controls and procedures
are effective in alerting them in a timely manner to material information relating to their company
(including its consolidated subsidiaries, if any) required to be included in periodic filings with
the SEC.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;Changes in internal controls.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There have been no changes in Southern Company&#146;s, Alabama Power&#146;s, Georgia Power&#146;s, Gulf
Power&#146;s, Mississippi Power&#146;s, or Southern Power&#146;s internal control over financial reporting (as
such term is defined in Rules&nbsp;13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934)
during the third quarter of 2006 that have materially affected or are reasonably likely to
materially affect Southern Company&#146;s, Alabama Power&#146;s, Georgia Power&#146;s, Gulf Power&#146;s, Mississippi
Power&#146;s, or Southern Power&#146;s internal control over financial reporting.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->32<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="111"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt">CONDENSED STATEMENTS OF COMPREHENSIVE INCOME (UNAUDITED)
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="114"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<br>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>



<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">THIRD QUARTER 2006 vs. THIRD QUARTER 2005<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2006 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2005
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Alabama Power operates as a vertically integrated utility providing electricity to retail customers
within its traditional service area located within the State of Alabama and to wholesale customers
in the Southeast. Many factors affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Alabama Power&#146;s
business of selling electricity. These factors include the ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to recover rising costs
related to growing demand and increasingly stringent environmental standards.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alabama Power continues to focus on several key performance indicators. These indicators
include customer satisfaction, plant availability, system reliability, and net income. For
additional information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; OVERVIEW &#150;
&#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Earnings</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Alabama Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the third quarter 2006 was
$238.0&nbsp;million compared to $236.1&nbsp;million for the corresponding period of 2005. Earnings in the
third quarter 2006 increased by $1.9&nbsp;million, or 0.8%.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alabama Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the year-to-date 2006 was
$438.2&nbsp;million compared to $451.0&nbsp;million for the corresponding period of 2005. Earnings
year-to-date 2006 decreased by $12.8&nbsp;million, or 2.8% primarily due to increases in other
operations expense related mainly to steam power, transmission and distribution maintenance
expense, interest expense associated with additional long-term debt, and depreciation and
amortization expense as a result of additional plant-in-service. These increases in expense were
partially offset by an increase in retail base revenues due to favorable weather conditions during
2006 and a 1.2% increase in retail rates that took effect January&nbsp;1, 2006 under Alabama Power&#146;s
environmental rate order approved by the Alabama PSC. See Note 3 to the financial statements of
Alabama Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional
information on Alabama Power&#146;s rates.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->38<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

    <TD align="right">10,989</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right">&nbsp;</TD>

<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Retail revenues</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, retail revenues increased by 13.7% compared to the same period in
the prior year. Energy and other cost recovery revenues which include the recovery of costs
associated with fuel, purchased power and PPAs certified by the Alabama PSC, and revenues
associated with the replenishment of Alabama Power&#146;s natural disaster reserve, generally do not
affect net income. Excluding these revenues, retail revenues increased by $27.5&nbsp;million, or 3.6%,
for the third quarter 2006 when compared to the corresponding period in 2005. The increase was
primarily due to a 2.9% increase in KWH energy sales for the third quarter when compared to the
corresponding period in 2005, as well as the retail rate increase in January&nbsp;2006 to recover
environmental costs. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;PSC
Matters &#150; Retail Rate Adjustments&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial
statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#150;Rate CNP&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the
Form 10-K. KWH energy sales to residential and commercial customers increased 3.3% and 1.7%,
respectively, when compared to the third quarter 2005 due to favorable weather conditions. KWH
energy sales to industrial customers increased 3.2% for the third quarter 2006 when compared to the
corresponding period of 2005 as a result of increased sales demand in the forest products and
automotive and plastic sectors.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, retail revenues increased 15.2% compared to the same period in the
prior year. Excluding energy and other cost recovery revenues as mentioned above, retail revenues
increased $88.7&nbsp;million, or 4.8%, year-to-date 2006 when compared to the corresponding period in
2005. The increase was primarily due to a 2.7% increase in KWH energy sales for year-to-date 2006
when compared to the corresponding period in 2005, as well as the retail rate increase in January
2006 to recover environmental costs. KWH energy sales to residential and commercial customers
increased 4.9% and 2.8%, respectively, due to favorable weather conditions in the first nine months
of 2006. KWH energy sales to industrial customers increased 0.9% in 2006 as a result of increased
sales demand in the forest products and automotive and plastic sectors.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->39<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Sales for resale &#150; non-affiliates</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Energy sales to non-affiliates will vary depending on the market cost of available energy
compared to the cost of Alabama Power and Southern Company system owned generation, demand for
energy within the Southern Company service territory, and availability of Southern Company system
generation.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
third quarter 2006 variance when compared to the third quarter 2005
was not material.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Year-to-date 2006 when compared to the same period in 2005, revenues from sales for resale to
non-affiliates increased $58.8&nbsp;million primarily due to a 12.8% increase in price while KWH sales
remained relatively flat. The 2006 price increases were generally the result of an increase in the
average cost of fuel. These transactions did not have a significant impact on earnings since
energy is usually sold at variable cost.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Sales for resale &#150; affiliates</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Energy sales to affiliated companies within the Southern Company system vary from period to
period depending on demand and the availability and cost of generating resources at each company.
These sales are made in accordance with the IIC, as approved by the FERC.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, revenues from sales for resale to affiliates decreased $44.4
million when compared to the same period in 2005 primarily due to a 53.5% decrease in KWH sales to
affiliates as well as a 14.8% decrease in price.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Year-to-date 2006, revenues from sales for resale to affiliates decreased $94.2&nbsp;million due to
a 40.1% decrease in KWH sales while price per KWH remained relatively flat. The decline in
revenues from sales to affiliates was a result of a decrease in availability of Alabama Power&#146;s
generating resources for such sales due to increased KWH sales growth in Alabama Power&#146;s service
territory during 2006 and a 35.5% decrease in hydro generation. These transactions did not have a
significant impact on earnings since energy is generally sold at marginal cost.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fuel expense, Purchased power &#150; non-affiliates, and Purchased power &#150; affiliates</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, total fuel and purchased power expense increased $70.8&nbsp;million when
compared to the corresponding period in 2005. The increase was due to a $53.7&nbsp;million increase in
the cost of fuel and $17.1&nbsp;million related to greater KWHs generated and purchased.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, total fuel and purchased power expense increased $241.1&nbsp;million when
compared to the corresponding period in 2005. The increase was due to a $205.9&nbsp;million increase in
the cost of fuel and a $35.2&nbsp;million increase related to greater KWHs generated and purchased.
Details of the individual components follow.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter of 2006, fuel expense was $102.2&nbsp;million higher when compared to the
corresponding period in 2005 due to a 13.0% increase in the average cost of coal and a 3.4%
increase in overall generation from Alabama Power-owned facilities partially offset by a 11.0%
decrease in natural gas prices.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->40<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, the increase in fuel expense of $240.0&nbsp;million is mainly due to a 13.8%
increase in the average cost of coal and a 12.7% increase in natural gas prices. Overall
generation from Alabama Power-owned facilities remained relatively flat for the first nine months
of 2006 compared to the same period in 2005. These transactions did not have a significant impact
on earnings since energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues through Alabama Power&#146;s
energy cost recovery clause.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Energy purchases from non-affiliates will vary depending on market cost of available energy
being lower than Southern Company system-generated energy, demand for energy within the service
territory, and availability of Southern Company system generation.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, purchased power from non-affiliates decreased $29.5&nbsp;million
compared to the same period in 2005 due to a 17.0% decrease in the amount of energy purchased and a
16.4% decrease in price.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, purchased power from non-affiliates decreased $33.0&nbsp;million when
compared to the same period in 2005 mainly due to a 15.2% decrease in energy purchased and a 7.2%
decrease in price. These transactions did not have a significant impact on earnings since energy
purchases are generally offset by energy revenues through Alabama Power&#146;s energy cost recovery
clause.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Energy purchases from affiliates will vary depending on demand and the availability and cost
of generating resources at each company within the Southern Company system. These purchases are
made in accordance with the IIC, as approved by the FERC.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The third quarter 2006 variance in purchased power from affiliates when compared to the third
quarter 2005 is not material.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Year-to-date 2006, purchased power from affiliates increased $34.1&nbsp;million when compared to
the same period in 2005 mainly due to a 21.8% increase in the amount of energy purchased as a
result of increased demand and a 3.9% decrease in price. These transactions did not have a
significant impact on earnings since energy purchases are generally offset by energy revenues
through Alabama Power&#146;s energy cost recovery clause.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Other operations expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The third quarter 2006 variance when compared to the third quarter 2005 is not material.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Year-to-date 2006, the increase in other operations expense of $31.7&nbsp;million is primarily due
to a $6.3&nbsp;million increase in steam power expenses related mainly to engineering and supervision
charges and rent expense, a $5.7&nbsp;million increase in nuclear power expenses related to regulatory
fees and labor costs, a $4.2&nbsp;million increase in transmission expense associated with load
dispatching, external electric purchases and system planning, a $3.9&nbsp;million increase in customer
accounts chiefly due to increases in uncollectible account expenses, and a $3.6&nbsp;million increase in
distribution expenses related to engineering and supervision charges, and meter expenses.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Maintenance expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, maintenance expense increased $21.0&nbsp;million when compared to the
same period in 2005 due to a $20.7&nbsp;million increase in transmission and distribution expenses
primarily associated with the 2006 natural disaster reserve accrual and amortization of deferred
storm expense. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;PSC Matters
&#150; Natural Disaster Cost Recovery&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements
of Alabama Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#151; Natural Disaster Cost Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, maintenance expense increased $23.0&nbsp;million when compared to the same
period in 2005, which reflects the recording of $45&nbsp;million additional transmission and
distribution expense in 2005 as a result of the Alabama PSC accounting order to offset the costs of
the damage from Hurricane Ivan in September&nbsp;2004 and to restore a balance in the natural disaster
reserve. Excluding the natural disaster reserve impacts of the 2005 accounting order, maintenance
expense increased $68.0&nbsp;million year-to-date 2006 when compared to
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->41<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">the same period in 2005. This increase was due to a $48.8&nbsp;million increase in transmission and
distribution expenses primarily associated with the 2006 natural disaster reserve accrual,
amortization of deferred storm expense, and maintenance of overhead lines. In addition, steam
power maintenance expense increased $6.7&nbsp;million primarily due to outage maintenance cost at
various coal plants. Nuclear power maintenance expense increased $6.2&nbsp;million mainly due to
increases in labor and nuclear outage expenses, and administrative and general maintenance expense
increased $3.0&nbsp;million associated with general structures.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Depreciation and amortization</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For both the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, depreciation and amortization expense
increased $5.4&nbsp;million and $18.1&nbsp;million, respectively, due to an increase in property, plant, and
equipment related to steam power and distribution capital projects when compared to the same
periods in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increases of $11.0&nbsp;million and $26.6&nbsp;million in interest expense, net of amounts
capitalized for the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, respectively, when compared to the same
periods in 2005 are primarily due to a $426&nbsp;million increase in long-term debt outstanding at
September&nbsp;30, 2006 when compared to September&nbsp;30, 2005. For additional information, see
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Financing Activities&#148;
of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Financing
Activities&#148; herein.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Other income (expense), net</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The third quarter 2006 variance when compared to the third quarter 2005 is not material.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Year-to-date 2006, other income, net decreased $6.7&nbsp;million when compared to year-to-date 2005
mainly due to the consent decree entered into in June&nbsp;2006 with the EPA in the NSR litigation. See
FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150; New Source Review Litigation&#148; and Note (B)&nbsp;to
the Condensed Financial Statements under &#147;NEW SOURCE REVIEW ACTIONS &#150; New Source Review Litigation&#148;
herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Income taxes</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The third quarter 2006 variance when compared to the third quarter 2005 is not material.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, income tax expense increased $38.6&nbsp;million when compared to the
corresponding period in 2005. In accordance with the Alabama PSC accounting order described above
under &#147;Maintenance expense,&#148; Alabama Power returned $27.7&nbsp;million of regulatory liabilities related
to deferred income taxes to its retail customers in 2005. The remainder of the increase in income
tax expense for year-to-date 2006 compared to the same period in 2005 primarily reflects the $17.3
million tax effect of the additional maintenance expenses recorded under the accounting order in
2005. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;PSC Matters &#150;
Natural Disaster Cost Recovery&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements
of Alabama Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#150; Natural Disaster Cost Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
Form 10-K and Note (J)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Alabama Power&#146;s future
earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous factors that affect the
opportunities, challenges, and risks of Alabama Power&#146;s business of selling electricity. These
factors include Alabama Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory environment that continues
to allow for the recovery of all prudently incurred costs.
Future earnings in the near term will depend, in part, upon growth in energy sales, which is
subject to a number of factors. These factors include weather, competition, new energy contracts
with neighboring utilities, energy
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->42<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and
the rate of economic growth in Alabama Power&#146;s service area. For additional information relating
to these issues, see RISK FACTORS in Item&nbsp;1A and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE
EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be fully recovered in rates on a timely basis. As discussed in the
Form 10-K, environmental compliance spending over the next several years may exceed amounts
estimated. Some of the factors driving the anticipated increase are higher commodity costs, market
demand for labor, and scope additions and clarifications. The timing, specific requirements, and
estimated costs could also change as environmental regulations are modified. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Alabama Power in
Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Alabama Power under &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; in
Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>New Source Review Litigation</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150; New
Source Review Actions&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Alabama
Power under &#147;Environmental Matters &#150; New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information regarding a civil action brought by the EPA alleging that Alabama Power had
violated the NSR provisions of the Clean Air Act and related state laws with respect to certain of
its coal-fired generating facilities. On June&nbsp;19, 2006, the U.S. District Court for the Northern
District of Alabama entered a consent decree between Alabama Power and the EPA, resolving alleged
NSR violations at Plant Miller. The consent decree required Alabama Power to pay $100,000 to
resolve the government&#146;s claim for a civil penalty and donate $4.9&nbsp;million of sulfur dioxide
emission allowances to a nonprofit charitable organization. As a result, Alabama Power has
recognized $5&nbsp;million in other income (expense), net related to the consent decree. The consent
decree also formalizes specific emissions reductions to be accomplished by Alabama Power,
consistent with other Clean Air Act programs that require emissions reductions. On August&nbsp;14,
2006, the district court granted Alabama Power&#146;s motion for summary judgment and entered a final
judgment in favor of Alabama Power on the EPA&#146;s claims related to Plants Barry, Gaston, Gorgas, and
Greene County, based on the district court&#146;s previous ruling regarding the correct legal tests and
stipulations entered between the parties. The plaintiffs have appealed this decision to the U.S.
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The final resolution of these claims is dependent on
these appeals and possible further court action and, therefore, cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>New Source Review Reform Rules</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;17, 2006, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit vacated the EPA&#146;s
October&nbsp;2003 proposed rule which sought to clarify the scope of the existing Routine Maintenance,
Repair, and Replacement Exclusion. Because this rule was not yet in effect, the court&#146;s ruling is
not anticipated to have any impact on Alabama Power. In September&nbsp;2006, the
EPA also proposed additional rules intended to clarify the test for determining when an emissions
increase subject to the NSR permitting requirements has occurred. The potential impact of these
proposed rules will depend on the adoption of final rules by the EPA. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150; New Source Review Actions&#148; of
Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->43<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Birmingham Area Eight-Hour Ozone Attainment Redesignation</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Environmental Matters -
Environmental Statutes and Regulations &#151; Air Quality&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K
for additional information regarding nonattainment designations for the eight-hour ozone air
quality standard. On May&nbsp;12, 2006, the EPA published a final rule approving the State of Alabama&#146;s
request to redesignate the Birmingham eight-hour ozone nonattainment area to attainment under the
standard. The EPA also approved a revision to the Alabama state implementation plan, containing a
maintenance plan to ensure the area&#146;s continued compliance with the standard and to address any
future exceedances of the standard. The EPA&#146;s redesignation determination became effective on June
12, 2006.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fine Particulate Matter Regulations</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters -
Environmental Statutes and Regulations &#151; Air Quality&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K
for additional information regarding nonattainment designations for the fine particulate matter air
quality standard. On September&nbsp;21, 2006, the EPA published a final rule lowering the 24-hour fine
particulate matter standard even further and plans to designate nonattainment areas based on the
new standard by December&nbsp;2009. On September&nbsp;30, 2006, the EPA also published its final rule for
implementation of the existing fine particulate matter standard. State plans for addressing the
nonattainment designations under the existing standard are required by April&nbsp;2008 and could require
further reductions in SO<SUB style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-bottom">2</SUB> and NOx emissions from power plants. The final outcome of
this matter cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FERC and Alabama PSC Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC Matters &#150;
Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements
of Alabama Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K
for information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for measuring
generation market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to assess
Southern Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory. Alabama Power has
authorization from the FERC to sell power to non-affiliates, including short-term opportunity
sales, at market-based prices. Specific FERC approval must be obtained with respect to a
market-based sale to an affiliate. On February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company submitted additional
information related to generation dominance in its retail service territory. Any new
market-based rate sales by any subsidiary of Southern Company in its retail service territory
entered into after February&nbsp;27, 2005 will be subject to refund to the level of the default
cost-based rates, pending the outcome of the proceeding. Such sales through May&nbsp;27, 2006, the
end of the 15-month refund period, were approximately $4&nbsp;million for Alabama Power. In the
event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures for entities that are found to have market
power are ultimately applied, Alabama Power may be required to charge cost-based rates for
certain wholesale sales in the Southern Company retail service territory, which may be lower
than negotiated market-based rates. The final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in
which the final methodology for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be
ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated an investigation to determine whether Southern
Company satisfies the other three parts of the FERC&#146;s market-based rate analysis: transmission
market power, barriers to entry, and affiliate abuse or reciprocal dealing. The FERC
established a new 15-month refund period
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->44<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>ALABAMA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">related to this expanded investigation. Any new market-based rate sales involving any Southern
Company subsidiary will be subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders lower rates as a
result of this new investigation, with the refund period beginning July&nbsp;19, 2005. The impact of
such sales involving Alabama Power through September&nbsp;30, 2006 is not expected to exceed $14.3
million, of which $3.1&nbsp;million relates to sales inside the retail service territory discussed
above. The FERC also directed that this expanded proceeding be held in abeyance pending the
outcome of the proceeding on the IIC discussed below. In its order in the IIC proceeding of
October&nbsp;5, 2006, pertaining to issues that overlap those in this proceeding, the FERC indicated
that it would issue an order in this expanded proceeding within 90&nbsp;days, seeking comment on the issues that may remain
appropriate for investigation as well as procedures for addressing those issues.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alabama Power believes that there is no meritorious basis for this proceeding and is
vigorously defending itself in this matter. However, the final outcome of this matter, including
any remedies to be applied in the event of an adverse ruling in this proceeding, cannot now be
determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated a new proceeding to examine (1)&nbsp;the provisions of the IIC
among Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, Savannah Electric, Southern
Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of which the power pool of Southern Company is
operated, and, in particular, the propriety of the continued inclusion of Southern Power as a
party to the IIC, (2)&nbsp;whether any parties to the IIC have violated the FERC&#146;s standards of
conduct applicable to utility companies that are transmission providers, and (3)&nbsp;whether
Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct defining Southern Power as a &#147;system company&#148; rather than a
&#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just and reasonable. In connection with the formation of Southern
Power, the FERC authorized Southern Power&#146;s inclusion in the IIC in 2000. The FERC also
previously approved Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct. The FERC order directs that the ALJ who
presided over a proceeding involving approval of PPAs between Southern Power and Georgia Power
and Savannah Electric be assigned to preside over the hearing in this proceeding and that the
testimony and exhibits presented in that proceeding be preserved to the extent appropriate.
Effective July&nbsp;19, 2005, revenues from transactions under the IIC involving any Southern Company
subsidiaries will be subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders any changes to the IIC.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;11, 2006, Southern Company, Calpine Corporation, Coral Energy, and Dalton
Utilities filed a settlement offer that would resolve the proceeding, and does not require any
refunds. The ALJ certified the settlement to the FERC, which on October&nbsp;5, 2006 issued an order
accepting the settlement subject to Southern Company&#146;s agreement to accept certain modifications
to its terms. On October&nbsp;20, 2006, Southern Company notified the FERC that it accepted the
modifications. The modifications largely involve functional separation and information
restrictions related to marketing activities conducted on behalf of Southern Power. Southern
Company filed with the FERC on November&nbsp;6, 2006 an implementation plan to comply with
the modifications set forth in the order. The impact of the modifications is currently being
assessed but is not expected to be material. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Intercompany Interchange
Contract&#148; of Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Alabama Power
under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Intercompany Interchange Contract&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.
</DIV>

Power&#146;s under recovered fuel costs as of September&nbsp;30, 2006 totaled $334.2&nbsp;million as compared to
$285.1&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2005. Alabama Power increased its fuel billing factor in January
2006 in accordance with Rate
