<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fine Particulate Matter Regulations</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150;
&#147;Environmental Matters &#150; Environmental Statutes and
Regulations &#150; Air Quality&#148; of Georgia Power in
Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information regarding nonattainment designations for the
fine particulate matter air quality standard. On September&nbsp;21, 2006, the EPA published a final
rule lowering the 24-hour fine particulate matter standard even further and plans to designate
nonattainment areas based on the new standard by December&nbsp;2009. On September&nbsp;30, 2006, the EPA
also published its final rule for implementation of the existing fine particulate matter standard.
State plans for addressing the nonattainment designations under the existing standard are required
by April&nbsp;2008 and could require further reductions in SO<SUB style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-bottom">2</SUB> and NOx emissions from power
plants. The final outcome of this matter cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;30, 2006, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit ruled in favor of Georgia
Power on its appeal and reversed the district court&#146;s order regarding certain alleged opacity
violations at Plant Wansley. The court of appeals remanded the case to the U.S. District Court for
the Northern District of Georgia for further proceedings consistent with its decision. The
ultimate outcome of this matter cannot now be determined. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS
- - FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental
Matters &#150; Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the
financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Environmental
Matters &#150; Plant Wansley Environmental
Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FERC and Georgia PSC Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC Matters &#150;
Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of
Georgia Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for measuring generation
market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to assess Southern Company&#146;s
generation dominance within its retail service territory. Georgia Power has authorization from the
FERC to sell power to non-affiliates, including short-term opportunity sales, at market-based
prices. Specific FERC approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based sale to an
affiliate. On February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company submitted additional information related to
generation dominance in its retail service territory. Any new market-based rate sales by any
subsidiary of Southern Company in its retail service territory entered into after February&nbsp;27, 2005
will be subject to refund to the level of the default cost-based rates, pending the outcome of the
proceeding. Such sales through May&nbsp;27, 2006, the end of the 15-month refund period, were
approximately $5.8&nbsp;million for Georgia Power. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation
measures for entities that are found to have market power are ultimately applied, Georgia Power may
be required to charge cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales in the Southern Company retail
service territory, which may be lower than negotiated market-based rates. The final outcome of
this matter will depend on the form in which the final methodology for assessing generation market
power and mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated an investigation to determine whether Southern
Company satisfies the other three parts of the FERC&#146;s market-based rate analysis: transmission
market power, barriers to
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->62<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">entry, and affiliate abuse or reciprocal dealing. The FERC established a new 15-month refund
period related to this expanded investigation. Any new market-based rate sales involving any
Southern Company subsidiary will be subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders lower rates as
a result of this new investigation, with the refund period beginning July&nbsp;19, 2005. The impact of
such sales involving Georgia Power through September&nbsp;30, 2006 is not expected to exceed $18.4
million, of which $3.9&nbsp;million relates to sales inside the retail service territory discussed
above. The FERC also directed that this expanded proceeding be held in abeyance pending the
outcome of the proceeding on the IIC discussed below. In its order in the IIC proceeding of
October&nbsp;5, 2006, pertaining to issues that overlap those in this proceeding, the FERC indicated
that it would issue an order in this expanded proceeding within 90&nbsp;days, seeking comment on the issues that may remain
appropriate for investigation as well as procedures for addressing those issues.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Georgia Power believes that there is no meritorious basis for this proceeding and is
vigorously defending itself in this matter. However, the final outcome of this matter, including
any remedies to be applied in the event of an adverse ruling in this proceeding, cannot now be
determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated a new proceeding to examine (1)&nbsp;the provisions of the IIC
among Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, Savannah Electric, Southern
Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of which the power pool of Southern Company is
operated, and, in particular, the propriety of the continued inclusion of Southern Power as a
party to the IIC, (2)&nbsp;whether any parties to the IIC have violated the FERC&#146;s standards of
conduct applicable to utility companies that are transmission providers, and (3)&nbsp;whether
Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct defining Southern Power as a &#147;system company&#148; rather than a
&#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just and reasonable. In connection
with the formation of Southern Power, the FERC authorized Southern Power&#146;s inclusion in the IIC in 2000. The FERC
also previously approved Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct. The FERC order directs that the
ALJ who presided over a proceeding involving approval of PPAs between Southern Power and Georgia
Power and Savannah Electric be assigned to preside over the hearing in this proceeding and that
the testimony and exhibits presented in that proceeding be preserved to the extent appropriate.
Effective July&nbsp;19, 2005, revenues from transactions under the IIC involving any Southern Company
subsidiaries will be subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders any changes to the IIC.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;11, 2006, Southern Company, Calpine Corporation, Coral Energy, and Dalton
Utilities filed a settlement offer that would resolve the proceeding, and does not require any
refunds. The ALJ certified the settlement to the FERC, which on October&nbsp;5, 2006 issued an order
accepting the settlement subject to Southern Company&#146;s agreement to accept certain modifications
to its terms. On October&nbsp;20, 2006, Southern Company notified the FERC that it accepted the
modifications. The modifications largely involve functional separation and information
restrictions related to marketing activities conducted on behalf of Southern Power. Southern
Company filed with the FERC on November&nbsp;6, 2006 an implementation plan to comply with
the modifications set forth in the order. The impact of the
modifications is currently
being assessed but
is not expected to be material. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE
EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Intercompany Interchange Contract&#148; of Georgia Power in Item
7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Intercompany
Interchange Contract&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->63<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Retail Fuel Cost Recovery</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In March&nbsp;2006, Georgia Power and Savannah Electric filed a combined request for fuel cost recovery
rate changes with the Georgia PSC to be effective July&nbsp;1, 2006, the effective date of the merger of
Savannah Electric into Georgia Power. On June&nbsp;15, 2006, the Georgia PSC ruled on the request and
approved an increase in Georgia Power&#146;s total annual fuel billings of approximately $400&nbsp;million.
The Georgia PSC order provided for a combined ongoing fuel forecast but reduced the requested
increase related to such forecast by $200&nbsp;million. The Georgia PSC order included no disallowances
of previously incurred fuel costs. Estimated under recovered fuel costs are to be recovered over
35&nbsp;months ending May&nbsp;2009 for customers in the former Georgia Power territory and over 41&nbsp;months
ending November&nbsp;2009 for customers in the former Savannah Electric territory. The order also
required Georgia Power to file for a new fuel cost recovery rate on a semi-annual basis, beginning
in September&nbsp;2006. Accordingly, on September&nbsp;15, 2006, Georgia Power filed a request to recover
fuel costs incurred through August&nbsp;2006 by increasing the fuel cost recovery rate. In October
2006, Georgia Power agreed with the Georgia PSC to file a supplementary request, by November&nbsp;13,
2006, reflecting a forecast of annual fuel costs, as well as updated information for previously
incurred fuel costs. The Georgia PSC is scheduled to rule on the entire request in February&nbsp;2007,
with the new rates to become effective on March&nbsp;1, 2007. As of September&nbsp;30, 2006, Georgia Power
had an under recovered fuel balance of approximately $952&nbsp;million, of which $762&nbsp;million is
currently included in the fuel cost recovery rate. Fuel cost recovery revenues as recorded on the
financial statements are adjusted for differences in actual recoverable costs and amounts billed in
current regulated rates. Accordingly, any changes in the billing factor will have no significant
effect on Georgia Power&#146;s revenues or net income, but will affect cash flow. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;PSC Matters &#150; Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; of Georgia
Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory
Matters &#150; Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (H)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Merger</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">With respect to the merger between Georgia Power and Savannah Electric, which was completed on July
1, 2006, the Georgia PSC voted on June&nbsp;15, 2006 to set the Merger Transition Adjustment (MTA)
applicable to customers in the former Savannah Electric service territory so that the new fuel rate
plus the MTA equals the applicable fuel rate paid by such customers as of June&nbsp;30, 2006. Amounts
collected under the MTA are being credited to customers in the former Georgia Power service
territory through a Merger Transition Credit (MTC). The MTA and the MTC will be in effect until
December&nbsp;31, 2007, when Georgia Power&#146;s base rates are scheduled to be adjusted.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Nuclear</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;PSC Matters &#150; Nuclear&#148; in
Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for information on Georgia Power&#146;s involvement in nuclear initiatives. On
August&nbsp;15, 2006, as part of a potential expansion of Plant Vogtle, Georgia Power and its affiliate,
Southern Nuclear Operating Company, Inc. (SNC),&nbsp;have filed an application with the NRC for an early
site permit (ESP)&nbsp;on behalf of the owners of Plant Vogtle. In addition, Georgia Power and SNC
notified the NRC of their intent to apply for a combined construction and operating license (COL)
in 2008. Ownership agreements have been signed with each of the existing Plant Vogtle co-owners.
In February&nbsp;2006, Georgia Power filed a request with the Georgia PSC to establish an accounting
order that would allow Georgia Power to defer for future recovery the ESP and COL costs, of which
Georgia Power&#146;s portion is estimated to total approximately $51&nbsp;million over the next four years.
On June&nbsp;22, 2006, the Georgia PSC approved the request. At this point, no final decision has been
made regarding actual construction. Any new generation resource must be certified by the Georgia
PSC in a separate proceeding.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->64<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Georgia Power has entered into three PPAs for a total of approximately 1,000 MW annually from
June&nbsp;2009 through May&nbsp;2024. These agreements were approved by the Georgia PSC on October&nbsp;2, 2006.
These agreements satisfy approximately 550 MW of growth, replace an existing 450 MW agreement that
expires in May&nbsp;2009, and are expected to result in higher operating and maintenance expenses that
will be subject to recovery through future base rates.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On February&nbsp;23, 2006, approximately 170 current and former employees of Georgia Power filed a
collective action against Georgia Power in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of
Georgia, alleging that Georgia Power violated the Fair Labor Standards Act by failing to properly
compensate certain employees (primarily linemen and crew leaders whose work is governed by a union
collective bargaining agreement) while the employees were subject to being called back into work
under on-call work rules and regulations. During the discovery period, approximately 40 of the
plaintiffs asked to be dismissed from the case. After reaching agreement that Georgia Power will
not seek to recover fees and costs from the plaintiffs, all of the remaining plaintiffs had
dismissed their claims as of October&nbsp;24, 2006. The matter is now concluded.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Georgia Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course of
business. In addition, Georgia Power&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive governmental
regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and
claims of various types, including
property damage, personal injury, and citizen enforcement of environmental requirements such as
opacity and other air quality standards, has increased generally throughout the United States. In
particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials
have become more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such pending or potential litigation against
Georgia Power cannot be predicted at this time;
however, for current proceedings not specifically reported herein or in Note 3 to the financial
statements of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K, management does not anticipate that the
liabilities, if any, arising from such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on
Georgia Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various other
contingencies, regulatory matters, and other matters being litigated which may affect future
earnings potential.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Georgia Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the
financial statements of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Georgia Power&#146;s results of
operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could produce estimates
that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial
statements. Also see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of
Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
complete discussion of Georgia Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to
Electric Utility Regulation, Contingent Obligations, and Unbilled Revenues.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->65<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Stock Options</I>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On January&nbsp;1, 2006, Georgia Power adopted FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123(R), &#147;Share-Based Payment,&#148; using
the modified prospective method. This statement requires that compensation cost relating to
share-based payment transactions be recognized in the financial statements. That cost will be
measured based on the grant date fair value of the equity or liability instruments issued.
Although the compensation expense required under the revised statement differs slightly, the
impacts on Georgia Power&#146;s financial statements are similar to the pro forma disclosures previously
included in Note 1 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Stock Options&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K and in Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Income Taxes</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In July&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued Interpretation No.&nbsp;48 (FIN 48), &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income
Taxes.&#148; This interpretation requires that tax benefits must be &#147;more likely than not&#148; of being
sustained in order to be recognized. The provisions of FIN 48 must be applied to all tax positions
beginning January&nbsp;1, 2007. Georgia Power is currently assessing the impact of FIN 48. The impact
on Georgia Power&#146;s financial statements has not yet been determined.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fair Value Measurement</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;157 (SFAS No.&nbsp;157), &#147;Fair Value Measurements&#148; in September&nbsp;2006.
This standard provides guidance on how to measure fair value where it is permitted or required
under other accounting pronouncements. SFAS No.&nbsp;157 also requires additional disclosures about
fair value measurements. Georgia Power will adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;157 on January&nbsp;1, 2008 and is currently
assessing the impact of this standard.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Pensions and Other Postretirement Plans</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;158 (SFAS No.&nbsp;158), &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting for Defined Benefit
Pension and Other Postretirement Plans &#150; an amendment of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;87, 88, 106, and
132(R)&#148; in September&nbsp;2006. This standard requires companies to fully recognize, as an asset or
liability, the overfunded or underfunded status of its benefits plans on the balance sheet.
Georgia Power will adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;158 with a prospective application as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and is
currently assessing the requirements under this standard. The impact on Georgia Power&#146;s balance
sheet has not yet been determined. SFAS No.&nbsp;158 also requires employers to measure the funded
status of plan assets and obligations as of the year-end balance sheet date. The new measurement
date requirement is effective for Georgia Power as of December&nbsp;31, 2008 and will require
recognition of the net periodic benefit cost for the three-month transition period between
September&nbsp;30 and December&nbsp;31, 2007 through retained earnings as of January&nbsp;1, 2008.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Guidance on Considering the Materiality of Misstatements</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In September&nbsp;2006, the SEC issued Staff Accounting Bulletin No.&nbsp;108 (SAB 108), &#147;Considering the
Effects of Prior Year Misstatements when Quantifying Misstatements in Current Year Financial
Statements.&#148; SAB 108 addresses how the effects of prior year uncorrected misstatements should be
considered when quantifying misstatements in current year financial statements. SAB 108 requires
companies to quantify misstatements using both a balance sheet and an income statement approach and
to evaluate whether either approach results in quantifying an error that is material in light of
relevant quantitative and qualitative factors. When the effect of initial adoption is material,
companies will record the effect as a cumulative effect adjustment to beginning of

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->66<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">year retained earnings. The provisions of SAB 108 are effective for Georgia Power for the year
ending December&nbsp;31, 2006. The adoption of SAB 108 is not expected to have a material impact on
Georgia Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Overview</B>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Georgia Power&#146;s financial condition remained stable at September&nbsp;30, 2006. Net cash
provided from operating activities decreased $10.2&nbsp;million for the first nine months of 2006
compared to the same period in 2005. The decrease in 2006 is primarily the result of higher fuel
inventories and an increase in under recovered fuel costs. Year-to-date 2006, gross property
additions were $817.6&nbsp;million. These additions were primarily related to the construction of
transmission and distribution facilities, purchases of nuclear fuel, and purchases of equipment to
comply with environmental standards. The majority of funds for these additions and other capital
requirements were derived primarily from operating activities and capital contributions from
Southern Company. See Georgia Power&#146;s Condensed Statements of Cash Flows herein for further
details.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> &#150;</FONT> &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Georgia Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, scheduled
maturities of long-term debt, as well as related interest, lease obligations, purchase commitments,
and trust funding requirements. Since December&nbsp;31, 2005, Georgia Power entered into three PPAs
that are expected to result in additional obligations of $55&nbsp;million in 2009 through 2010 and $483
million thereafter. Approximately $303&nbsp;million will be required by September&nbsp;30, 2007 for
redemptions and maturities of long-term debt.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, Georgia Power has entered into five new contracts for the purchase of uranium
concentrates and uranium enrichment services at Plants Hatch and Vogtle that result in additional
obligations of approximately $38&nbsp;million in 2007 through 2008, $60&nbsp;million in 2009 through 2010,
and $63&nbsp;million thereafter. These costs are expected to be recovered through Georgia Power&#146;s fuel
cost recovery clause. See Note 7 to the financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Fuel
Commitments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Georgia Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from sources
similar to those utilized in the past, which were primarily operating cash flows, with capital
contributions from Southern Company, short-term debt, and external security issuances providing
additional funds. However, the amount, type and timing of any future financings, if needed, will
depend on maintenance of adequate earnings, prevailing market conditions, regulatory approval, and
other factors. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150;
&#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At September&nbsp;30, 2006, Georgia Power&#146;s current liabilities exceeded current assets primarily
due to the use of short-term debt as a funding source to meet cash needs, which can fluctuate
significantly due to the seasonality of the business. To meet short-term cash needs and
contingencies, Georgia Power had at September&nbsp;30, 2006 approximately $17.1&nbsp;million of cash and cash
equivalents and $903&nbsp;million of unused credit arrangements with banks, of which $40&nbsp;million expire
in 2007 and $863&nbsp;million expire in 2011. Of the facilities that expire in 2007, all contain
provisions allowing two-year term loans executable at expiration. See Note 6 to the financial
statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Bank Credit Arrangements&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information. Georgia Power expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed, prior to
expiration.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->67<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">These unused credit arrangements provide liquidity support to Georgia Power&#146;s obligations with
respect to variable rate pollution control bonds and commercial paper. Georgia Power may also meet
short-term cash needs through a Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial
paper and extendible commercial notes at the request and for the benefit of Georgia Power and other
Southern Company subsidiaries. At September&nbsp;30, 2006, Georgia Power had approximately $648&nbsp;million
of commercial paper and $50&nbsp;million of bank loans outstanding. Management believes that the need
for working capital can be adequately met by utilizing commercial paper programs and lines of
credit without maintaining large cash balances.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Georgia Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in payment
schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain contracts
that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of a credit rating change
to BBB- or Baa3 or below. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity purchases and
sales. At September&nbsp;30, 2006, the maximum potential collateral requirements at a BBB- or Baa3
rating were approximately $8&nbsp;million. The maximum potential collateral requirements at a rating
below BBB- or Baa3 were approximately $327&nbsp;million. Generally, collateral may be provided for by a
Southern Company guaranty, letter of credit, or cash. Georgia Power, along with all members of the
Southern Company power pool, is also party to certain derivative agreements that could require
collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a credit rating change to below investment
grade for it and/or Alabama Power. These agreements are primarily for natural gas price risk
management activities. At September&nbsp;30, 2006, Georgia Power&#146;s total exposure to these types of
agreements was approximately $25&nbsp;million.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Georgia Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have
not changed materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2005 reporting period. In addition, Georgia
Power is not aware of any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in
the near term.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulations, Georgia Power has limited exposure to market volatility in
interest rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks
relative to movements in electricity prices, Georgia Power enters into physical fixed-price
contracts for the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market.
Georgia Power has also implemented a fuel hedging program at the instruction of the Georgia PSC.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value of derivative energy contracts at September&nbsp;30, 2006 was as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unrealized gains and losses from mark to market adjustments on derivative contracts related to
Georgia Power&#146;s fuel hedging programs are recorded as regulatory assets and liabilities. Realized
gains and losses from these programs are included in fuel expense and are recovered through Georgia
Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery mechanism. Through June&nbsp;30, 2006, Georgia Power was allowed to retain
25% of any net gains under an existing Georgia PSC order. In connection with the fuel cost
recovery decision, effective July&nbsp;1, 2006, the Georgia PSC ordered the suspension of the profit
sharing framework related to the fuel hedging program. New profit sharing arrangements as well as
other changes to the fuel hedging program are currently under development. Such changes are not
expected to have a material impact on Georgia Power&#146;s financial statements. See Note 3 to the
financial statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#150; Fuel Hedging Program&#148; in
Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information. Gains and losses on derivative contracts that
are not designated as hedges are recognized in the statements of income as incurred. At September
30, 2006, the fair value gain / (loss)&nbsp;of all derivative energy contracts was reflected in the
financial statements as follows:
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="88%">&nbsp;</TD>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Georgia Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial
statements of Georgia Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (F)
to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In January&nbsp;2006, all outstanding shares of Georgia Power&#146;s 4.60% series of preferred stock were
redeemed. In February&nbsp;2006, Georgia Power redeemed $150&nbsp;million of Series&nbsp;G 6.200% Senior Notes.
Also during the first quarter, Georgia Power entered into two derivative transactions to reduce its
exposure to interest rate risk. The transactions consisted of an interest rate hedge of an
anticipated $150&nbsp;million senior note issuance in 2006 and an interest rate hedge of an anticipated
$225&nbsp;million senior note issuance in 2007.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In May&nbsp;2006, prior to the merger into Georgia Power, Savannah Electric redeemed $20&nbsp;million
6.9% First Mortgage Bonds due May&nbsp;1, 2006.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->69<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GEORGIA POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2006, Georgia Power incurred obligations in connection with the issuance of $10.1
million Auction Rate Pollution Control Revenue Bonds. The proceeds were used to defease and redeem
in July&nbsp;2006 a like amount of 5.25% Pollution Control Revenue Bonds.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with Savannah Electric&#146;s merger into Georgia Power, all of Savannah Electric&#146;s
obligations under five series of senior notes outstanding at June&nbsp;30, 2006, totaling $195&nbsp;million,
and the obligations related to three series of pollution control revenue bonds, totaling $18
million together with interest rate swaps for $14&nbsp;million, were assumed by Georgia Power. Georgia
Power also assumed Savannah Electric&#146;s commercial paper and extendible commercial note obligations
of $84&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, at the time of the merger, each of the 1,800,000 outstanding shares of Savannah
Electric&#146;s preferred stock was cancelled and converted into one share of Georgia Power 6 1/8%
Series&nbsp;Class&nbsp;A Preferred Stock, Non-Cumulative, Par Value $25 Per Share.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July&nbsp;2006, Georgia Power incurred obligations in connection with the issuance of $67
million 4.40% Pollution Control Revenue Bonds and $48.7&nbsp;million 4.90% Pollution Control Revenue
Bonds. Proceeds from the sales were used to defease and redeem in August&nbsp;2006 of $67&nbsp;million of
5.0% Pollution Control Revenue Bonds and $48.7&nbsp;million of 5.25% Pollution Control Revenue Bonds.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements and
contractual obligations, Georgia Power plans to continue, when economically feasible, a program to
retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital if market
conditions permit.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->70<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="126"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>



<DIV align="Center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">THIRD QUARTER 2006 vs. THIRD QUARTER 2005<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2006 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2005

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power operates as a vertically integrated utility providing electricity to retail customers
within its traditional service area located in northwest Florida and to wholesale customers in the
Southeast. Many factors affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Gulf Power&#146;s business
of selling electricity. These factors include the ability to maintain a stable regulatory
environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs, and to recover rising costs.
These costs include those related to growing demand, increasingly stringent environmental
standards, fuel prices, and storm restoration costs. Appropriately balancing environmental
expenditures with customer prices will continue to challenge Gulf Power for the foreseeable future.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Hurricanes Dennis and Katrina hit Gulf Power&#146;s service territory in July&nbsp;2005 and August&nbsp;2005,
respectively. As a result of these storms, as well as Hurricane Ivan in September&nbsp;2004, Gulf Power
has incurred significant restoration costs. Florida PSC actions in July&nbsp;2006 should assure the
timely recovery of these costs, while minimizing the impact upon Gulf Power&#146;s customers. See
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;PSC Matters &#151; Storm Damage
Cost Recovery&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC and
Florida PSC Matters &#151; Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148; and Note (K)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gulf Power continues to focus on several key performance indicators. These indicators include
customer satisfaction, plant availability, system reliability, and net income. For additional
information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; OVERVIEW &#151; &#147;Key
Performance Indicators&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Earnings</B>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred and preference stock for the third quarter
2006 was $34.6&nbsp;million compared to $37.2&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2005. Earnings in
the third quarter 2006 decreased by $2.6&nbsp;million, or 7.0%, primarily due to a decrease in retail
revenues, excluding revenues related to fuel and other cost recovery;
increased dividends resulting from the issuance of $55&nbsp;million
of preference stock in November 2005; and increased interest expense, net of
amounts capitalized.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gulf Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred and preference stock for year-to-date
2006 was $69.0&nbsp;million compared to $73.3&nbsp;million for the corresponding period in 2005. Earnings
year-to-date 2006 decreased by $4.3&nbsp;million, or 5.8%, primarily
due to increased dividends resulting from the issuance of
$55&nbsp;million of preference stock in November 2005 and
increased interest expense, net of amounts
capitalized.
</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->76<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Retail revenues</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, retail revenues increased by 7.9% when compared to the
corresponding period in 2005. Excluding revenues related to fuel and other cost recovery, which do
not affect net income, retail revenues decreased by $1.6&nbsp;million, or 1.2%, for the third quarter
2006 compared to the corresponding period in the prior year. This decrease, primarily due to lower
market-driven industrial rates, occurred despite higher retail energy sales. Retail energy sales
to residential, commercial, and industrial customers increased by 0.5%, 2.8%, and 2.2%,
respectively, in the third quarter 2006, when compared to the same period in the prior year. The
increased sales to residential and commercial customers in the third quarter were due primarily to
customer growth, offset by less-favorable weather. Increased energy sales to the industrial
customer class were primarily due to strength in the petroleum segment. Other cost recovery for
the third quarter 2006 includes approximately $8.1&nbsp;million of revenues related to recovery of
incurred costs for storm damage activity as approved by the Florida PSC.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, retail revenues increased by 11.9% when compared to the corresponding
period in 2005. Excluding revenues related to fuel and other cost recovery, which do not affect
net income, retail revenues increased by $6.1&nbsp;million, or 1.9%, year-to-date 2006 as compared to
the corresponding period in the prior year. Retail energy sales to residential, commercial, and
industrial customers increased by 3.1%, 3.9%, and 1.7%, respectively, year-to-date 2006, when
compared to the same period in the prior year. The increased sales
for year-to-date 2006 were primarily
due to customer growth and more favorable weather. Other cost recovery for year-to-date 2006
includes approximately $20.5&nbsp;million of revenues related to recovery of incurred costs for storm
damage activity as approved by the Florida PSC. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Gulf
Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#151; Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and
FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC and Florida PSC Matters &#151; Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148; and Note (K)&nbsp;to
the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information on storm damage cost recovery.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->77<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Sales for resale &#151; affiliates</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenues from sales for resale to affiliates will vary depending on demand and the
availability and cost of generating resources at each company within the Southern Company system.
These affiliate sales are made in accordance with the IIC, as approved by the FERC. These
transactions do not have a significant impact on earnings since this energy is generally sold at
marginal cost.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, sales for resale to affiliates increased by 36.7%
and 42.8%, respectively, compared to the corresponding periods in 2005, primarily as a result of
increased sales of available generation to meet system demand.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Other revenues</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, other revenues increased $0.8&nbsp;million and $2.2
million, respectively, when compared to the same periods in 2005, primarily as a result of higher
franchise fees, which have no impact on earnings. Franchise fees are generally proportional to
sales revenue and are offset by franchise and gross receipt taxes.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fuel expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, fuel expense increased $46.9&nbsp;million when compared to the same
period in 2005 due to a $30.0&nbsp;million increase in the cost of fuel and related costs and a $16.9
million increase resulting from an increase in total KWHs generated.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, fuel expense increased $101.6&nbsp;million when compared to the same period
in 2005 due to a $69.9&nbsp;million increase in the cost of fuel and related costs and a $31.7&nbsp;million
increase resulting from an increase in total KWHs generated. Since energy expenses are generally
offset by energy revenues through Gulf Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery mechanism, these expenses do not
have a material impact on net income. See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC and Florida PSC
Matters &#151; Fuel Cost Recovery&#148; herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Purchased power &#151; non-affiliates</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, purchased power from non-affiliates decreased $6.5&nbsp;million when
compared to the same period in 2005 due to a $2.1&nbsp;million decrease in KWH purchases and a $4.4
million decrease resulting from lower average cost per net KWH.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, purchased power from non-affiliates decreased $7.2&nbsp;million when
compared to the same period in 2005 due to a $3.8&nbsp;million decrease in KWH purchases and a $3.4
million decrease resulting from the lower average cost per net KWH.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since energy expenses are generally offset by revenues through Gulf Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery
mechanism, these expenses do not have a significant impact on net income.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->78<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Purchased power &#151; affiliates</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Purchased power from affiliates will vary depending on demand and the availability and cost of
generating resources at each company within the Southern Company system. These purchases are made
in accordance with the IIC, as approved by the FERC.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, purchased power from affiliates decreased $13.6&nbsp;million when
compared to the same period in 2005. Decreased KWH purchases reduced expenses by $31.0&nbsp;million.
This was partially offset by a $17.4&nbsp;million increase resulting from higher average cost per net
KWH.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, purchased power from affiliates decreased $8.3&nbsp;million when compared to
the same period in 2005 due to a $19.6&nbsp;million decrease in KWH purchases, partially offset by an
$11.3&nbsp;million increase resulting from the higher average cost per net KWH.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Other operations expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In third quarter and year-to-date 2006, other operations expense increased $1.8&nbsp;million and
$17.1&nbsp;million, respectively, when compared to the same periods in 2005, primarily due to the
recovery of storm restoration costs as approved by the Florida PSC. Since these costs are
recognized as revenues are collected, there is no impact on net income. See Note 3 to the
financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#151; Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC and Florida PSC Matters &#151; Storm
Damage Cost Recovery&#148; and Note (K)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional
information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Maintenance expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The third quarter 2006 variance when compared to the third quarter 2005 is not material.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, maintenance expense decreased $3.3&nbsp;million when compared to the same
period in 2005 primarily due to a delay in scheduled maintenance performed on power generation
facilities in 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Depreciation and amortization</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, depreciation and amortization increased $0.9
million and $3.2&nbsp;million, respectively, when compared to the same periods in 2005, due to the
construction of two major generation projects that were placed in service in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Taxes other than income taxes</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, taxes other than income taxes increased $1.7
million and $5.1&nbsp;million, respectively, when compared to the same periods in 2005, primarily as a
result of increases in franchise and gross receipts taxes, which are directly related to increases
in retail revenues.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Interest expense, net of amounts capitalized</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, interest expense, net of amounts capitalized
increased $1.0&nbsp;million and $2.8&nbsp;million, respectively, when compared to the same periods in 2005.
The increase was primarily due to higher interest rates on variable rate pollution control bonds
and short-term borrowing, and the issuance of $60&nbsp;million in senior notes in August&nbsp;2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Gulf Power&#146;s future
earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous factors that affect the
opportunities, challenges, and risks of
Gulf Power&#146;s business of selling electricity. These factors include Gulf Power&#146;s ability to
maintain a stable regulatory environment that continues to allow for the recovery of all prudently
incurred costs. Future earnings in the near term will depend, in part, upon growth in energy
sales, which is subject to a number of factors. These factors include weather, competition, new
energy contracts with neighboring utilities, energy conservation practiced by customers, the price
of electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and the rate of economic growth in Gulf Power&#146;s
service area. For additional information relating to these issues, see RISK
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->79<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">FACTORS in Item&nbsp;1A and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Gulf
Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be fully recovered in rates on a timely basis. As discussed in the
Form 10-K, environmental compliance spending over the next several years may exceed amounts
estimated. Some of the factors driving the anticipated increase are higher commodity costs, market
demand for labor, and scope additions and clarifications. The timing, specific requirements, and
estimated costs could also change as environmental regulations are modified. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Gulf Power in
Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8
of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>New Source Review Reform Rules</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;17, 2006, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit vacated the EPA&#146;s
October&nbsp;2003 proposed rule which sought to clarify the scope of the existing Routine Maintenance,
Repair, and Replacement Exclusion. Because this rule was not yet in effect, the court&#146;s ruling is
not anticipated to have any impact on Gulf Power. In September&nbsp;2006, the
EPA also proposed additional rules intended to clarify the test for determining when an emissions
increase subject to the NSR permitting requirements has occurred. The potential impact of these
proposed rules will depend on the adoption of final rules by the EPA. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Environmental Matters &#151; New Source Review Actions&#148; of
Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fine Particulate Matter Regulations</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Environmental Matters -
Environmental Statutes and Regulations &#151; Air Quality&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for
additional information regarding nonattainment designations for the fine particulate matter air
quality standard. On September&nbsp;21, 2006, the EPA published a final rule lowering the 24-hour fine
particulate matter standard even further and plans to designate nonattainment areas based on the
new standard by December&nbsp;2009. On September&nbsp;30, 2006, the EPA also published its final rule for
implementation of the existing fine particulate matter standard. State plans for addressing the
nonattainment designations under the existing standard are required by April&nbsp;2008 and could require
further reductions in SO<SUB style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-bottom">2</SUB> and NOx emissions from power plants. The final outcome of
this matter cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FERC and Florida PSC Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> &#151;</FONT> FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC Matters
&#151; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements
of Gulf Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#151; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for measuring
generation market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to assess
Southern Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory. Gulf Power has authorization from the
FERC to sell power to non-affiliates, including short-term opportunity sales, at market-based
prices. Specific FERC approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based sale to an
affiliate. On February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company submitted additional information related to
generation dominance in its retail service
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->80<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">territory. Any new market-based rate sales by any subsidiary of Southern Company in its retail
service territory entered into after February&nbsp;27, 2005 will be subject to refund to the level of
the default cost-based rates, pending the outcome of the proceeding. Such sales through May&nbsp;27,
2006, the end of the 15-month refund period, were approximately $0.8&nbsp;million for Gulf Power. In
the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation measures for entities that are found to have market
power are ultimately applied, Gulf Power may be required to charge cost-based rates for certain
wholesale sales in the Southern Company retail service territory, which may be lower than
negotiated market-based rates. The final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in
which the final methodology for assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be
ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated an investigation to determine whether Southern
Company satisfies the other three parts of the FERC&#146;s market-based rate analysis: transmission
market power, barriers to entry, and affiliate abuse or reciprocal dealing. The FERC established a
new 15-month refund period related to this expanded investigation. Any new market-based rate sales
involving any Southern Company subsidiary will be subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders
lower rates as a result of this new investigation, with the refund period beginning July&nbsp;19, 2005.
The impact of such sales involving Gulf Power through September&nbsp;30, 2006 is not expected to exceed
$3&nbsp;million, of which $0.6&nbsp;million relates to sales inside the retail service territory discussed
above. The FERC also directed that this expanded proceeding be held in abeyance pending the
outcome of the proceeding on the IIC discussed below. In its order in the IIC proceeding of
October&nbsp;5, 2006, pertaining to issues that overlap those in this proceeding, the FERC indicated
that it would issue an order in this expanded proceeding within 90&nbsp;days, seeking comment on the issues that may remain
appropriate for investigation as well as procedures for addressing those issues.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gulf Power believes that there is no meritorious basis for this proceeding and is vigorously
defending itself in this matter. However, the final outcome of this matter, including any remedies
to be applied in the event of an adverse ruling in this proceeding, cannot now be determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated a new proceeding to examine (1)&nbsp;the provisions of the IIC
among Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, Savannah Electric, Southern
Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of which the power pool of Southern Company is
operated, and, in particular, the propriety of the continued inclusion of Southern Power as a
party to the IIC, (2)&nbsp;whether any parties to the IIC have violated the FERC&#146;s standards of
conduct applicable to utility companies that are transmission providers, and (3)&nbsp;whether
Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct defining Southern Power as a &#147;system company&#148; rather than a
&#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just and reasonable. In connection with the formation of Southern
Power, the FERC authorized Southern Power&#146;s inclusion in the IIC in 2000. The FERC also
previously approved Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct. The FERC order directs that the ALJ who
presided over a proceeding involving approval of PPAs between Southern Power and Georgia Power
and Savannah Electric be assigned to preside over the hearing in this proceeding and that the
testimony and exhibits presented in that proceeding be preserved to the extent appropriate.
Effective July&nbsp;19, 2005, revenues from transactions under the IIC involving any Southern Company
subsidiaries will be subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders any changes to the IIC.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;11, 2006, Southern Company, Calpine Corporation, Coral Energy, and Dalton
Utilities filed a settlement offer that would resolve the proceeding, and does not require any
refunds. The ALJ certified the settlement to the FERC, which on October&nbsp;5, 2006 issued an order
accepting the settlement subject to Southern Company&#146;s agreement to accept certain modifications
to its terms. On October&nbsp;20, 2006, Southern Company notified the FERC that it accepted the
modifications. The modifications largely involve functional separation and information
restrictions related to marketing activities conducted on behalf of Southern Power.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->81<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
