<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern
Company filed with the FERC on November&nbsp;6, 2006 an implementation plan to
comply with the modifications set forth in the order. The impact of the modifications is
currently being assessed but is not expected to be material. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC Matters &#151; Intercompany
Interchange Contract&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Gulf
Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#151; Intercompany Interchange Contract&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Storm Damage Cost Recovery</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note 1 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Property Damage Reserve&#148; and Note 3 to
the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Retail Regulatory Matters &#151; Storm Damage Cost
Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on how Gulf Power maintains a reserve for
property damage to cover the cost of damages from major storms to its transmission and distribution
facilities and the cost of uninsured damages to its generation facilities and other property, and
the impact of recent hurricanes on that reserve.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July&nbsp;2005 and August&nbsp;2005, Hurricanes Dennis and Katrina, respectively, hit the Gulf Coast
of the United States and caused significant damage within Gulf Power&#146;s service area. Hurricane
Ivan hit the Gulf Coast of Florida and Alabama in September&nbsp;2004, also causing significant damage
to Gulf Power&#146;s service area. Gulf Power was authorized by the Florida PSC to defer the portion of
the hurricane restoration costs that exceeded the balance in its property damage reserve account.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July&nbsp;2006, the Florida PSC issued its order approving a stipulation and settlement between
Gulf Power and several consumer groups that resolved all matters relating to Gulf Power&#146;s request
for recovery of incurred costs for storm-recovery activities, the replenishment of Gulf Power&#146;s
property damage reserve, and the related request for permission to issue $87.2&nbsp;million in
securitized storm-recovery bonds. The order provides for an extension of the storm-recovery
surcharge currently being collected by Gulf Power for an additional 27&nbsp;months, expiring in June
2009, in lieu of the requested issuance of storm-recovery bonds.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;According to the stipulation, the funds resulting from the extension of the current surcharge
will first be credited to the unrecovered balance of storm-recovery costs associated with Hurricane
Ivan until these costs have been fully recovered. The funds will then be credited to the property
reserve for recovery of the storm-recovery costs of $52.6&nbsp;million associated with Hurricanes Dennis
and Katrina that were previously charged to the reserve. Should revenues collected by Gulf Power
through the extension of the storm-recovery surcharge exceed the storm-recovery costs associated
with Hurricanes Dennis and Katrina, the excess revenues will be credited to the reserve.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The annual accrual to the reserve of $3.5&nbsp;million and Gulf Power&#146;s limited discretionary
authority to make additional accruals to the reserve will continue as previously approved by the
Florida PSC. As part of the March&nbsp;2005 agreement regarding Hurricane Ivan costs that established
the existing surcharge, Gulf Power agreed that it would not seek any additional increase in its
base rates and charges to become effective on or before March&nbsp;1, 2007. The terms of the
stipulation do not alter or affect that portion of the prior agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;According to the order, in the case of future storms, if Gulf Power incurs cumulative costs
for storm-recovery activities in excess of $10&nbsp;million during any calendar year, Gulf Power will be
permitted to file a streamlined formal request for an interim surcharge. Any interim surcharge
would provide for the recovery, subject to refund,
of up to 80% of the claimed costs for storm-recovery activities. Gulf Power would then petition
the Florida PSC for full recovery through an additional surcharge or other cost recovery mechanism.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of September&nbsp;30, 2006, Gulf Power had recovered $41.8&nbsp;million of the costs allowed for
storm-recovery activities and the deficit balance in the property damage reserve account totaled
approximately $43.1&nbsp;million, of
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->82<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">which approximately $16.6&nbsp;million and $26.5&nbsp;million, respectively, are included in the Condensed
Balance Sheets herein under &#147;Current Assets&#148; and &#147;Deferred Charges and Other Assets.&#148;
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fuel Cost Recovery</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power has established fuel cost recovery rates approved by the Florida PSC. In 2005 and
the first nine months of 2006, Gulf Power has experienced higher than expected fuel costs for
coal and natural gas. If the projected fuel revenue over or under recovery exceeds 10% of the
projected fuel costs for the period, Gulf Power is required to notify the Florida PSC and
indicate if an adjustment to the fuel cost recovery factor is being requested. Gulf Power filed
such notice with the Florida PSC on July&nbsp;21, 2006, but no adjustment to the factor was
requested. Under recovered fuel costs at September&nbsp;30, 2006 totaled $69.1&nbsp;million, and are
included in &#147;Under Recovered Regulatory Clause Revenues&#148; on Gulf Power&#146;s Condensed Balance
Sheets herein. Fuel cost recovery revenues, as recorded on the financial statements, are
adjusted for differences in actual recoverable costs and amounts billed in current regulated
rates. Accordingly, any change in the billing factor would have no significant effect on Gulf
Power&#146;s revenues or net income, but would affect cash flow.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Other Matters</B>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power has entered into two PPAs, one of which is with Southern Power, for a total of
approximately 487 MW annually from June&nbsp;2009 through May&nbsp;2014. The PPAs are the result of a
competitive request for proposals process initiated by Gulf Power in January&nbsp;2006 to address
anticipated need for additional capacity beginning in 2009. These PPAs are both subject to
approval by the Florida PSC for purposes of cost recovery through Gulf Power&#146;s capacity clause, and
the PPA with Southern Power is also subject to FERC approval.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gulf Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course of
business. In addition, Gulf Power&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive governmental
regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over environmental issues and
claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, and citizen enforcement of
environmental requirements such as opacity and other air quality standards, has increased generally
throughout the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged
exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such pending or
potential litigation against Gulf Power cannot be predicted at this time; however, for current
proceedings not specifically reported herein or in Note 3 to the financial statements of Gulf Power
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K, management does not anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising
from such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect on Gulf Power&#146;s financial
statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various other
contingencies, regulatory matters, and other matters being litigated which may affect future
earnings potential.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the
financial statements of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Gulf Power&#146;s results of operations and related disclosures. Different
assumptions and measurements could produce estimates that are significantly different from those
recorded in the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; ACCOUNTING
POLICIES &#151; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of
the Form 10-K for a
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->83<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">complete discussion of Gulf Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to Electric
Utility Regulation, Contingent Obligations, and Unbilled Revenues.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Stock Options</I>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On January&nbsp;1, 2006, Gulf Power adopted FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123(R), &#147;Share-Based Payment,&#148; using the
modified prospective method. This statement requires that compensation cost relating to share-based
payment transactions be recognized in the financial statements. That cost will be measured based on the
grant date fair value of the equity or liability instruments issued. Although the compensation
expense required under the revised statement differs slightly, the impacts on Gulf Power&#146;s
financial statements are similar to the pro forma disclosures previously included in Note 1 to the
financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Stock Options&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and in Note (C)
to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Income Taxes</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In July&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued Interpretation No.&nbsp;48 (FIN 48), &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income
Taxes.&#148; This interpretation requires that tax benefits must be &#147;more likely than not&#148; of being
sustained in order to be recognized. The provisions of FIN 48 must be applied to all tax positions
beginning January&nbsp;1, 2007. Gulf Power is currently assessing the impact of FIN 48. The impact on
Gulf Power&#146;s financial statements has not yet been determined.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fair Value Measurement</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;157 (SFAS No.&nbsp;157), &#147;Fair Value Measurements&#148; in September&nbsp;2006.
This standard provides guidance on how to measure fair value where it is permitted or required
under other accounting pronouncements. SFAS No.&nbsp;157 also requires additional disclosures about
fair value measurements. Gulf Power will adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;157 on January&nbsp;1, 2008 and is currently
assessing the impact of this standard.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Pensions and Other Postretirement Plans</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;158 (SFAS No.&nbsp;158), &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting for Defined Benefit
Pension and Other Postretirement Plans &#151; an amendment of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;87, 88, 106, and
132(R)&#148; in September&nbsp;2006. This standard requires companies to fully recognize, as an asset or
liability, the overfunded or underfunded status of its benefits plans on the balance sheet. Gulf
Power will adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;158 with a prospective application as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and is
currently assessing the requirements under this standard. The impact on Gulf Power&#146;s balance sheet
has not yet been determined. SFAS No.&nbsp;158 also requires employers to measure the funded status of
plan assets and obligations as of the year-end balance sheet date. The new measurement date
requirement is effective for Gulf Power as of December&nbsp;31, 2008 and will require recognition of the
net periodic benefit cost for the three-month transition period between September&nbsp;30 and December
31, 2007 through retained earnings as of January&nbsp;1, 2008.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Guidance on Considering the Materiality of Misstatements</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In September&nbsp;2006, the SEC issued Staff Accounting Bulletin No.&nbsp;108 (SAB 108), &#147;Considering the
Effects of Prior Year Misstatements when Quantifying Misstatements in Current Year Financial
Statements.&#148; SAB 108 addresses how the effects of prior year uncorrected misstatements should be
considered when quantifying misstatements in current year financial statements. SAB 108 requires
companies to quantify misstatements using
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->84<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">both a balance sheet and an income statement approach and to evaluate whether either approach
results in quantifying an error that is material in light of relevant quantitative and qualitative
factors. When the effect of initial adoption is material, companies will record the effect as a
cumulative effect adjustment to beginning of year retained earnings. The provisions of SAB 108 are
effective for Gulf Power for the year ending December&nbsp;31, 2006. The adoption of SAB 108 is not
expected to have a material impact on Gulf Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Overview</B>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power&#146;s financial condition remained stable at September&nbsp;30, 2006. Net cash provided from
operating activities totaled $117.3&nbsp;million for the first nine months of 2006, compared to $144.5
million for the corresponding period in 2005. The $27.2&nbsp;million decrease in 2006 resulted
primarily from a decrease in deferred income taxes. Gross property additions to utility plant were
$101.5&nbsp;million in the first nine months of 2006. Funds for Gulf Power&#146;s property additions were
provided by operating activities and other financing activities. See Gulf Power&#146;s Condensed
Statements of Cash Flows herein for further details.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> &#151;</FONT> &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Gulf Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, lease obligations,
preference stock dividends, purchase commitments, and trust funding requirements. Approximately
$25&nbsp;million will be required by September&nbsp;30, 2007 for maturities of long-term debt.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction and other purposes from sources
similar to those utilized in the past, which were primarily operating cash flows, with capital
contributions from Southern Company, short-term debt, and external security issuances providing
additional funds. However, the amount, type, and timing of any future financings, if needed, will
depend upon maintenance of adequate earnings, regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions,
and other factors. See<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND
LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional
information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At September&nbsp;30, 2006, Gulf Power&#146;s current liabilities exceeded current assets primarily due
to the scheduled maturity of $25&nbsp;million of long-term debt in 2006. To meet short-term cash needs
and contingencies, Gulf Power has various internal and external sources of liquidity. At September
30, 2006, Gulf Power had approximately $6.6&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents and $120&nbsp;million
of unused committed lines of credit with banks. Of these facilities, $60&nbsp;million expire in 2006 and
$60&nbsp;million expire in 2007. Of these credit arrangements, $60&nbsp;million contain provisions allowing
two-year term loans executable at expiration and $30&nbsp;million contain provisions allowing one-year
term loans executable at expiration. Gulf Power expects to renew its credit facilities, as needed,
prior to expiration. See Note 6 to the financial statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Bank Credit
Arrangements&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information. These credit arrangements
provide liquidity support to Gulf Power&#146;s obligations with respect to variable rate pollution control bonds
and commercial paper. A portion of these facilities may be used to fund or provide liquidity
support for commercial paper issuances to fund costs related to Hurricanes Ivan, Dennis, and
Katrina. In addition, Gulf Power has substantial cash flow from operating activities. Gulf Power
may also meet short-term cash needs through a
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->85<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>GULF POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Company subsidiary organized to issue and sell commercial paper and extendible commercial
notes at the request and for the benefit of Gulf Power and other Southern Company subsidiaries. At
September&nbsp;30, 2006, Gulf Power had outstanding $93.1&nbsp;million in commercial paper, $3.6&nbsp;million in
extendible commercial notes, and $50&nbsp;million in bank notes.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in payment
schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain contracts
that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of a credit rating change
to BBB- or Baa3, or below. Generally, collateral may be provided for by a Southern Company
guaranty, letter of credit, or cash. These contracts are primarily for physical electricity
purchases and sales. At September&nbsp;30, 2006, the maximum potential collateral requirements at a
BBB- or Baa3 rating were approximately $5&nbsp;million. The maximum potential collateral requirements
at a rating below BBB- or Baa3 were approximately $10&nbsp;million. Gulf Power, along with all members
of the Southern Company power pool, is also party to certain derivative agreements that could
require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a credit rating change to below
investment grade for Alabama Power and/or Georgia Power. These agreements are primarily for natural
gas price risk management activities. At September&nbsp;30, 2006, Gulf Power&#146;s total exposure to these
types of agreements was approximately $25&nbsp;million.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed materially
compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2005 reporting period. In addition, Gulf Power is not aware of any
facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near term.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulation, Gulf Power has limited exposure to market volatility in
interest rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks
relative to movements in electricity prices, Gulf Power enters into physical fixed-price contracts
for the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market. Gulf Power has
also implemented a fuel-hedging program with the approval of the Florida PSC.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unrealized gains and losses from mark-to-market adjustments on derivative contracts related to
Gulf Power&#146;s fuel hedging programs are recorded as regulatory assets and liabilities. Realized
gains and losses from these programs are included in fuel expense and are recovered through Gulf
Power&#146;s fuel cost recovery clause. Gains and losses on derivative contracts that are not
designated as hedges are recognized in the statements of income as incurred. At September&nbsp;30,
2006, the fair value gain / (loss)&nbsp;of derivative energy contracts was reflected in the financial
statements as follows:
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="88%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>

</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3"><I>(in thousands)</I></TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom" style="background: #cceeff">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Regulatory assets, net</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">(7,124</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>

</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unrealized pre-tax gains (losses)&nbsp;recognized in income were not material for any period
presented.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION
AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Gulf Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial
statements of Gulf Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note (F)&nbsp;to
the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Gulf Power did not issue or redeem any long-term securities in the first nine months of 2006. Gulf
Power&#146;s obligations in connection with pollution control bonds totaling $12.1&nbsp;million matured in
April&nbsp;2006. In the third quarter 2006, Gulf Power amended a derivative transaction to hedge the
interest rate risk of an anticipated future financing. The derivative has a total notional amount
of $80&nbsp;million and will be settled at the time of the future financing, with any resulting gain or
loss amortized over a 10-year period. For further details, see Note (F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial
Statements herein.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements, contractual
obligations, and storm-recovery, Gulf Power plans to continue, when economically feasible, a
program to retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations with lower-cost capital if
market conditions permit.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->87<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="132"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>



<DIV align="Center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">THIRD QUARTER 2006 vs. THIRD QUARTER 2005

</DIV>

<DIV align="Center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt">AND

</DIV>

<DIV align="Center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt">YEAR-TO-DATE 2006 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2005

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power operates as a vertically integrated utility providing electricity to retail
customers within its traditional service area located within the State of Mississippi and to
wholesale customers in the Southeast. Many factors affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks
of Mississippi Power&#146;s business of selling electricity. These factors include the ability to
maintain a stable regulatory environment, to achieve energy sales growth while containing costs,
and to recover costs related to growing demand, storm restoration, and increasingly stringent
environmental standards. Hurricane Katrina hit Mississippi Power&#146;s service territory in August
2005. As a result, Mississippi Power has incurred significant restoration costs. In addition,
fuel costs rose significantly during 2005 and the first nine months of 2006. Recent Mississippi
PSC actions should assure the timely recovery of the storm-recovery costs, while minimizing the
impact on Mississippi Power&#146;s customers. Mississippi Power will continue to work with the
Mississippi PSC to ensure timely recovery of the storm-recovery and fuel costs. See Note (I)&nbsp;to
the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information on the recent storm-recovery
order.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mississippi Power continues to focus on several key performance indicators. In recognition
that Mississippi Power&#146;s long-term financial success is dependent upon how well it satisfies its
customers&#146; needs, Mississippi Power&#146;s retail base rate mechanism, PEP, includes performance
indicators that directly tie customer service indicators to Mississippi Power&#146;s allowed return. In
addition to the PEP performance indicators, Mississippi Power focuses on other performance
measures, including broader measures of customer satisfaction, plant availability, system
reliability, and net income. For additional information on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; OVERVIEW &#151; &#147;Key Performance Indicators&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of
the Form 10-K.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Earnings</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the third quarter 2006 was
$36.6&nbsp;million compared to $28.2&nbsp;million for the corresponding period of 2005. In the third quarter
2006, earnings increased by $8.4&nbsp;million, or 29.7%, compared to the same period of 2005 primarily
as a result of the on-going recovery of Mississippi Power&#146;s service territory from Hurricane
Katrina and a retail base rate increase which became effective April&nbsp;2006.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mississippi Power&#146;s net income after dividends on preferred stock for the year-to-date 2006
was $74.7&nbsp;million compared to $70.8&nbsp;million for the corresponding period of 2005. Year-to-date
earnings in 2006 increased $3.9&nbsp;million, or 5.5%, compared to the same period of 2005 primarily as
a result of an increase in territorial base revenues of $16.9&nbsp;million, due to an increase in the
retail rates which became effective in April&nbsp;2006, an increase
in interest income of $2.7&nbsp;million, an increase in other income (expense), net of $2.9&nbsp;million, and
a decrease of $2.9&nbsp;million in maintenance expense. These increases to earnings were partially
offset by an increase of $10.3&nbsp;million in depreciation and amortization expense, an increase in
interest expense of $5.3&nbsp;million, and an increase in other operations expense of $1.9&nbsp;million.</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->93<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<DIV style="font-size: 3pt; margin-top: 16pt; width: 18%; border-top: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt">N/M &#150; Not meaningful
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Retail revenues</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, retail revenues increased 13.9% compared to the same period in the
prior year. Excluding revenues related to fuel and other cost recovery, which do not affect net
income, retail revenues increased 19.2% in the third quarter 2006 when compared to the same period
of 2005 due to a retail rate increase, increased sales due to warmer than normal weather, and the
on-going recovery of Mississippi Power&#146;s service territory from the effects of Hurricane Katrina.
In the third quarter 2006, KWH sales to residential, commercial, and industrial customers increased
9.7%, 5.7%, and 29.6%, respectively, when compared to the corresponding period in 2005 due to the
recovery from Hurricane Katrina.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, retail revenues increased 6.5% compared to the same period in the prior
year. Excluding revenues related to fuel and other cost recovery, which do not affect net income,
retail revenues increased 6.5% for the year-to-date 2006 when compared to the same period in 2005
due to a retail rate increase, warmer than normal weather, and the recovery from the effects of
Hurricane Katrina. Year-to-date 2006 KWH sales to residential and commercial customers decreased
2.4% and 6.6%, respectively, when compared to the corresponding period in 2005, due to the loss of
customers from Hurricane Katrina. At September&nbsp;30, 2005, approximately 19,200 customers remained
unable to receive service. At September&nbsp;30, 2006, approximately 13,300 customers remained unable
to receive service. Industrial KWH sales increased 4.8% for year-to-date 2006 over the same period
in 2005 due to warmer than normal weather and the on-going recovery from Hurricane Katrina.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Details of retail revenues are as follows:
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Sales for resale &#150; non-affiliates</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenues from sales for resale to non-affiliates will vary depending on the market cost of
available energy compared to the cost of Mississippi Power and Southern Company system owned
generation, demand for energy within the Southern Company service territory, and availability of
Southern Company system generation. These transactions do not have a significant impact on
earnings since the energy is generally sold at variable cost.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, sales for resale to non-affiliates decreased 7.8%
and 2.8%, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, primarily due to decreased
generation available for opportunity sales due to higher system demand.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Sales for resale </I>&#150; <I>affiliates</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenues from sales for resale to affiliates will vary depending on demand and the
availability and cost of generating resources at each company. These affiliate sales are made in
accordance with the IIC, as approved by the FERC. These transactions do not have a significant
impact on earnings since the energy is generally sold at marginal cost.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, sales for resale to affiliates increased 102.3%
and 19.7%, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, primarily due to generation not
required to serve Mississippi Power customers being available for sale to affiliates. This
generation was not available in the same periods of 2005 due to outages resulting from Hurricane
Katrina.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fuel expense and Purchased power expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, fuel expense and purchased power expense, together, increased $16.8
million compared to the same period in the prior year.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, fuel expense and purchased power expense, together, increased $18.3
million compared to the same period in the prior year. Details of the individual components follow.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, fuel expense increased by $59.0&nbsp;million when compared to the same
period in 2005 primarily due to an increase in fuel cost and a 35% increase in generation in the
third quarter 2006 when compared to the third quarter 2005 due to Hurricane Katrina-related plant
outages.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, the increase in fuel expense of $60.0&nbsp;million, as compared to the same
period in 2005, is primarily due to a 3.98% increase in generation and a 17.2% increase in fuel
expense per KWH. Since energy expenses are generally offset by energy revenues through Mississippi
Power&#146;s retail and wholesale fuel cost recovery clauses, these expenses do not have a significant
impact on earnings.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, purchased power expense &#150; non-affiliates decreased
$7.1&nbsp;million and $8.4&nbsp;million, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, primarily as
the result of increased generation in 2006 as compared to the same periods in 2005 due to Hurricane
Katrina-related plant outages.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, purchased power from affiliates decreased 79.9%
and 42.3%, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005 due to increased self generation.
In 2005, purchased power was higher than normal due to Hurricane Katrina-related plant outages.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Energy purchases from affiliated companies within the Southern Company system will vary
depending on demand and the availability and cost of generating resources at each company. These
purchases are made in accordance with the IIC, as approved by the FERC. These transactions did not
have a significant impact on earnings since the energy purchases are generally offset by energy
revenues through Mississippi Power&#146;s retail and wholesale fuel cost recovery clauses.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Other operations </I>expense
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, other operations expense increased $2.7&nbsp;million when compared to
the same period in 2005, primarily the result of increases of approximately $1.5&nbsp;million in
distribution expense, $0.6&nbsp;million in sales operation expense, and $0.3&nbsp;million in transmission
expense.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->95<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, other operations expense increased $1.9&nbsp;million when compared to the
same period in 2005, primarily as a result of a $1.7&nbsp;million increase in distribution expense.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Maintenance expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, maintenance expense increased 3.2% when compared to the same period
in 2005 resulting from the increased operation of the combined cycle units as gas costs decreased.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, maintenance expense decreased 5.6% when compared to the same period in
2005 due to the accrual of certain expenses arising from Hurricane Katrina related to the wholesale
portion of the business in 2005 and a decrease in distribution maintenance during 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Depreciation and amortization</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, depreciation and amortization expense increased
$2.3&nbsp;million and $10.3&nbsp;million, respectively, when compared to the same periods in 2005, primarily
due to the decrease in credit amortization of the regulatory liability related to the additional
Plant Daniel capacity and the new depreciation rates approved by the Mississippi PSC effective
January&nbsp;1, 2006. See Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail
Regulatory Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Interest income</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For both the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, interest income increased $2.7&nbsp;million, as
compared to the same periods in 2005 due to higher interest income related to the regulatory
recovery mechanism for fuel and energy cost hedging.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Interest expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, interest expense increased $0.9&nbsp;million, as compared to the same
period in 2005 due to higher interest rates.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, interest expense increased $5.3&nbsp;million, as compared to the same period
in 2005, due to the increase in short-term indebtedness and higher interest rates, and the reversal
of a $2.5&nbsp;million liability in June&nbsp;2005 for a transmission facility agreement as a result of
changes in the legal and regulatory environment.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Other income (expense), net</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, other income (expense), net increased $1.1&nbsp;million when compared to
the same period in 2005, primarily the result of an increase in revenues associated with customer
projects and a decrease in expense associated with employee-related expenses arising from Hurricane
Katrina.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, other income (expense), net increased $2.9&nbsp;million when compared to the
same period
in 2005, primarily the result of an increase of $1&nbsp;million in customer project revenues and a
decrease of approximately $1&nbsp;million in employee-related expenses arising from Hurricane Katrina.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Income taxes</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, income taxes increased $4.7&nbsp;million and $0.9
million, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005 primarily due to an increase in
pre-tax income.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Mississippi Power&#146;s
future earnings potential. The level of future earnings depends on numerous factors that affect
the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Mississippi Power&#146;s business of selling electricity.
These factors include Mississippi Power&#146;s ability to maintain a stable regulatory environment that
continues to allow for the recovery of all prudently incurred costs. Future earnings in the near
term will depend, in part, upon growth in energy sales, which is subject to a number of factors.
These factors include weather, competition, new energy contracts with neighboring utilities, energy
conservation practiced by customers, the price of electricity, the price elasticity of demand, and
the rate of economic growth in Mississippi Power&#146;s service area in the aftermath of Hurricane</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->96<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Katrina. For additional information relating to these issues, see RISK FACTORS in Item&nbsp;1A and
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and
Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of
the Form 10-K.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Environmental Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Compliance costs related to the Clean Air Act and other environmental regulations could affect
earnings if such costs cannot be fully recovered in rates on a timely basis. As discussed in the
Form 10-K, environmental compliance spending over the next several years may exceed amounts
estimated. Some of the factors driving the anticipated increase are higher commodity costs, market
demand for labor, and scope additions and clarifications. The timing, specific requirements, and
estimated costs could also change as environmental regulations are modified. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; of Mississippi Power
in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>New Source Review Reform Rules</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;17, 2006, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit vacated the EPA&#146;s
October&nbsp;2003 proposed rule which sought to clarify the scope of the existing Routine Maintenance,
Repair, and Replacement Exclusion. Because this rule was not yet in effect, the court&#146;s ruling is
not anticipated to have any impact on Mississippi Power. In September&nbsp;2006, the
EPA also proposed additional rules intended to clarify the test for determining when an emissions
increase subject to the NSR permitting requirements has occurred. The potential impact of these
proposed rules will depend on the adoption of final rules by the EPA. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION
AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental Matters &#150; New Source Review Actions&#148; of
Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FERC and Mississippi PSC Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> </FONT>&#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150;
&#147;FERC Matters &#150;
Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements
of Mississippi Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#150;Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K
for information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for measuring
generation market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to assess Southern
Company&#146;s generation dominance within its retail service territory. Mississippi Power has
authorization from the FERC to sell power to non-affiliates, including short-term opportunity
sales, at market-based prices. Specific FERC approval must be obtained with respect to a
market-based sale to an affiliate. On February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company submitted additional
information related to generation dominance in its retail service territory. Any new market-based
rate sales by any subsidiary of Southern Company in its retail service territory entered into after
February&nbsp;27, 2005 will be subject to refund to the level of the default cost-based rates, pending
the outcome of the proceeding. Such sales through May&nbsp;27, 2006, the end of the 15-month refund
period, were approximately $8.5&nbsp;million for Mississippi Power. In the event that the FERC&#146;s
default mitigation measures for entities that are found to have market power are ultimately
applied, Mississippi Power may be required to charge cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales
in the Southern Company retail service territory, which may be lower than negotiated market-based
rates. The final outcome of this matter will depend on the form in which the final methodology for
assessing generation market power and mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot be
determined at this time.</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->97<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated an investigation to determine whether Southern
Company satisfies the other three parts of the FERC&#146;s market-based rate analysis: transmission
market power, barriers to entry, and affiliate abuse or reciprocal dealing. The FERC established a
new 15-month refund period related to this expanded investigation. Any new market-based rate sales
involving any Southern Company subsidiary will be subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders
lower rates as a result of this new investigation, with the refund period beginning July&nbsp;19, 2005.
The impact of such sales involving Mississippi Power through September&nbsp;30, 2006 is not expected to
exceed $14.2&nbsp;million, of which $7.3&nbsp;million relates to sales inside the retail service territory
discussed above. The FERC also directed that this expanded proceeding be held in abeyance pending
the outcome of the proceeding on the IIC discussed below. In its order in the IIC proceeding of
October&nbsp;5, 2006, pertaining to issues that overlap those in this proceeding, the FERC indicated
that it would issue an order in this expanded proceeding within 90&nbsp;days, seeking comment on the issues that may remain
appropriate for investigation as well as procedures for addressing those issues.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mississippi Power believes that there is no meritorious basis for this proceeding and is
vigorously defending itself in this matter. However, the final outcome of this matter, including
any remedies to be applied in the event of an adverse ruling in this proceeding, cannot now be
determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated a new proceeding to examine (1)&nbsp;the provisions of the IIC
among Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, Savannah Electric, Southern
Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of which the power pool of Southern Company is
operated, and, in particular, the propriety of the continued inclusion of Southern Power as a
party to the IIC, (2)&nbsp;whether any parties to the IIC have violated the FERC&#146;s standards of
conduct applicable to utility companies that are transmission providers, and (3)&nbsp;whether
Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct defining Southern Power as a &#147;system company&#148; rather than a
&#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just and reasonable. In connection with the formation of Southern
Power, the FERC authorized Southern Power&#146;s inclusion in the IIC in 2000. The FERC also
previously approved Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct. The FERC order directs that the ALJ who
presided over a proceeding involving approval of PPAs between Southern Power and Georgia Power
and Savannah Electric be assigned to preside over the hearing in this proceeding and that the
testimony and exhibits presented in that proceeding be preserved to the extent appropriate.
Effective July&nbsp;19, 2005, revenues from transactions under the IIC involving any Southern Company
subsidiaries will be subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders any changes to the IIC.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;11, 2006, Southern Company, Calpine Corporation, Coral Energy, and Dalton
Utilities filed a settlement offer that would resolve the proceeding, and does not require any
refunds. The ALJ certified the settlement to the FERC, which on October&nbsp;5, 2006 issued an order
accepting the settlement subject to Southern Company&#146;s agreement to accept certain modifications
to its terms. On October&nbsp;20, 2006, Southern Company notified the FERC that it accepted the
modifications. The modifications largely involve functional separation and information
restrictions related to marketing activities conducted on behalf of Southern Power. Southern
Company filed with the FERC on November&nbsp;6, 2006 an implementation plan to comply with
the modifications set forth in the order. The impact of the modifications is currently being
assessed but is not expected to be material. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Intercompany Interchange
Contract&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi
Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Intercompany Interchange Contract&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->98<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Storm Damage Cost Recovery</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In
August&nbsp;2005, Hurricane Katrina hit the Gulf Coast of the United States and caused significant
damage within Mississippi Power&#146;s service area. Mississippi Power maintains a reserve to cover the
cost of damages from major storms to its transmission and distribution lines and the cost of
uninsured damages to its generation facilities and other property. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151;  &#147;PSC Matters &#151; Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148;
of Mississippi
Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 3 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Retail
Regulatory Matters &#151; Storm Damage Cost Recovery&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional
information.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
June&nbsp;2006, the Mississippi PSC issued an order based upon a stipulation between
Mississippi Power and the Mississippi Public Utilities Staff. The stipulation and the associated
order certified actual storm restoration costs relating to Hurricane Katrina through April&nbsp;30,
2006 of $267.9&nbsp;million and affirmed estimated additional costs through December&nbsp;31, 2007 of
$34.5&nbsp;million, for total storm restoration costs of $302.4&nbsp;million, without offset for the
property damage reserve of $3.0&nbsp;million. Of the total amount, $292.8&nbsp;million applies to
Mississippi Power&#146;s retail jurisdiction. The order directed Mississippi Power to file an
application with the Mississippi Development Authority (MDA)&nbsp;for Community Development Block
Grants (CDBG). All CDBG proceeds received by
Mississippi Power will be applied to both retail and wholesale storm restoration costs and will
be used to significantly mitigate the impacts of the cost of storm restoration on Mississippi
Power&#146;s customers. The retail portion of any certified restoration costs not covered by the
CDBG program are expected to be funded through a state bond program previously approved by the
State of Mississippi legislature. The Mississippi PSC order also indicated that the state bond
program would be appropriate funding for all or a portion of a new storm operations center if
approved and for an appropriate storm reserve, both of which require additional Mississippi PSC
action. If state bonds are used for any portion of the Hurricane Katrina restoration costs,
periodic true-up mechanisms will be structured to comply with terms and requirements from the
legislation.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Mississippi PSC order also granted continuing authority to record a regulatory asset in
an amount equal to the retail portion of the recorded Hurricane Katrina restoration costs. The
balance in the regulatory asset account at September&nbsp;30, 2006 is $264.3&nbsp;million, which is net of
the retail portion of insurance proceeds of $79.7&nbsp;million. These costs include approximately
$144.8&nbsp;million of capital additions and $119.5&nbsp;million of operation and maintenance
expenditures. Mississippi Power continues to report actual storm expenses to the Mississippi PSC
periodically. For any future event causing damage to property beyond the balance in the
reserve, the order also granted Mississippi Power the authority to record a regulatory asset.
Mississippi Power would then apply to the Mississippi PSC for recovery of such amounts or for
authority to otherwise dispose of the regulatory asset.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mississippi
Power filed the CDBG application with the MDA in September&nbsp;2006. On October
30, 2006, Mississippi Power received from the MDA a CDBG in the amount of $276.4&nbsp;million.
Mississippi Power filed an application for a financing order with the Mississippi PSC on July&nbsp;3,
2006 for restoration costs under the state bond program, including the property damage reserve
funding and the construction of the storm operations center. On October&nbsp;27, 2006, the
Mississippi PSC issued a financing order that authorizes the issuance of $121.2&nbsp;million of
system restoration bonds. This amount includes $25.2&nbsp;million for the retail storm recovery
costs not covered by the CDBG, $60&nbsp;million for a property damage reserve, and $36&nbsp;million for
the retail portion of the construction of the storm operations facility. The bonds will be
issued by the Mississippi State Bond Commission and will represent an obligation of the State of
Mississippi. The final outcome of this matter cannot now be
determined.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->99<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Retail Regulatory Matters</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In December&nbsp;2005, Mississippi Power submitted its annual PEP filing to the Mississippi PSC.
Ordinarily, PEP limits annual rate increases to 4%; however, Mississippi Power requested that
the Mississippi PSC approve a temporary change to allow it to exceed this cap as a result of the
ongoing effects of Hurricane Katrina. Mississippi Power had requested a 5.05%, or $32&nbsp;million,
retail base rate increase to become effective in April&nbsp;2006. Hearings were held in March&nbsp;2006
and the full increase was approved by the Mississippi PSC later in March&nbsp;2006.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February&nbsp;2006, Mississippi Power filed with the Mississippi PSC its annual ECO Plan
evaluation. Mississippi Power requested a 12 cent per 1,000 KWH reduction for retail customers.
This decrease would represent a reduction of approximately $1.3&nbsp;million per year in annual
revenues for Mississippi Power.
Hearings were held in April&nbsp;2006. The Mississippi PSC unanimously approved the decrease at the
hearings and issued an order confirming approval in April&nbsp;2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fuel Cost Recovery</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power has an established fuel cost recovery factor that is approved by the Mississippi
PSC. In 2005 and the first nine months of 2006, Mississippi Power experienced higher than expected
fuel costs for coal and gas, which led to an increase in the under recovered fuel costs.
Mississippi Power is required to file for an adjustment to the fuel cost recovery factor annually;
the last such filing was made in November&nbsp;2005, with the new rate becoming effective in January
2006. At September&nbsp;30, 2006, the under recovered balance of fuel recorded in Mississippi Power&#146;s
Condensed Balance Sheets herein was $68.2&nbsp;million. Mississippi Power&#146;s operating revenues are
adjusted for differences in actual recoverable fuel cost and amounts billed in accordance with the
currently approved cost recovery rate. Accordingly, changes to the billing factor will have no
significant effect on Mississippi Power&#146;s revenues or net income but will affect cash flow.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course of
business. In addition, Mississippi Power&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive
governmental regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over
environmental issues and claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, and
citizen enforcement of environmental requirements such as opacity and other air quality standards,
has increased generally throughout the United States. In particular, personal injury claims for
damages caused by alleged exposure to hazardous materials have become more frequent. The ultimate
outcome of such pending or potential litigation against Mississippi Power cannot be predicted at
this time; however, for current proceedings not specifically reported herein or in Note 3 to the
financial statements of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K, management does not
anticipate that the liabilities, if any, arising from such current proceedings would have a
material adverse effect on Mississippi Power&#146;s financial statements.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See the Notes to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various other
contingencies, regulatory matters, and other matters being litigated which may affect future
earnings potential.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1
to the financial statements of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of
these policies, certain estimates are made</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->100<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">that may have a material impact on Mississippi Power&#146;s results of operations and related
disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could produce estimates that are significantly
different from those recorded in the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS &#151; ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#150; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates&#148; of

Obligations, Unbilled Revenues, and Plant Daniel Operating Lease.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Stock Options</I>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On January&nbsp;1, 2006, Mississippi Power adopted FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123(R), &#147;Share-Based Payment,&#148;
using the modified prospective method. This statement requires that compensation cost relating to
share-based payment transactions be recognized in the financial statements. That cost will be
measured based on the grant date fair value of the equity or liability instruments issued.
Although the compensation expense required under
the revised statement differs slightly, the impacts on Mississippi Power&#146;s financial statements are
similar to the pro forma disclosures previously included in Note 1 to the financial statements of
Mississippi Power under &#147;Stock Options&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and in Note (C)&nbsp;to the Condensed
Financial Statements herein.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Income Taxes</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In July&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued Interpretation No.&nbsp;48 (FIN 48), &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income
Taxes.&#148; This interpretation requires that tax benefits must be &#147;more likely than not&#148; of being
sustained in order to be recognized. The provisions of FIN 48 must be applied to all tax positions
beginning January&nbsp;1, 2007. Mississippi Power is currently assessing the impact of FIN 48. The
impact on Mississippi Power&#146;s financial statements has not yet been determined.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fair Value Measurement</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;157 (SFAS No.&nbsp;157), &#147;Fair Value Measurements&#148; in September&nbsp;2006.
This standard provides guidance on how to measure fair value where it is permitted or required
under other accounting pronouncements. SFAS No.&nbsp;157 also requires additional disclosures about
fair value measurements. Mississippi Power will adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;157 on January&nbsp;1, 2008 and is
currently assessing the impact of this standard.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Pensions and Other Postretirement Plans</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;158 (SFAS No.&nbsp;158), &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting for Defined Benefit
Pension and Other Postretirement Plans &#150; an amendment of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;87, 88, 106, and
132(R)&#148; in September&nbsp;2006. This standard requires companies to fully recognize, as an asset or
liability, the overfunded or underfunded status of its benefits plans on the balance sheet.
Mississippi Power will adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;158 with a prospective application as of December&nbsp;31, 2006
and is currently assessing the requirements under this standard. The impact on Mississippi Power&#146;s
balance sheet has not yet been determined. SFAS No.&nbsp;158 also requires employers to measure the
funded status of plan assets and obligations as of the year-end balance sheet date. The new
measurement date requirement is effective for Mississippi Power as of December&nbsp;31, 2008 and will
require recognition of the net periodic benefit cost for the three-month transition period between
September&nbsp;30 and December&nbsp;31, 2007 through retained earnings as of January&nbsp;1, 2008.</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->101<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Guidance on Considering the Materiality of Misstatements</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In September&nbsp;2006, the SEC issued Staff Accounting Bulletin No.&nbsp;108 (SAB 108), &#147;Considering the
Effects of Prior Year Misstatements when Quantifying Misstatements in Current Year Financial
Statements.&#148; SAB 108 addresses how the effects of prior year uncorrected misstatements should be
considered when quantifying misstatements in current year financial statements. SAB 108 requires
companies to quantify misstatements using both a balance sheet and an income statement approach and
to evaluate whether either approach results in quantifying an error that is material in light of
relevant quantitative and qualitative factors. When the effect of initial adoption is material,
companies will record the effect as a cumulative effect adjustment to beginning of year retained
earnings. The provisions of SAB 108 are effective for Mississippi Power for the year ending
December&nbsp;31, 2006. The adoption of SAB 108 is not expected to have a material impact on Mississippi
Power&#146;s financial statements.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Overview</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s financial condition remained stable at September&nbsp;30, 2006. Net cash
provided from operating activities totaled $103.1&nbsp;million for the first nine months of 2006,
compared to net cash flow provided from operating activities of $84.5&nbsp;million for the same
period in 2005. The $18.6&nbsp;million increase in the first nine months of 2006 resulted primarily
from reduced revenues in the third quarter 2005 due to the impact of Hurricane Katrina.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Mississippi Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, lease
obligations, purchase commitments, preferred stock dividends, and trust funding requirements.
Mississippi Power has no maturities or redemptions of long-term debt required by September&nbsp;30,
2007.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power plans to obtain the funds required for construction, continued storm damage
restoration, and other purposes from sources similar to those used in the past, including operating
cash flows, capital contributions from Southern Company, short-term debt, and external security
issuances. The amount, type, and timing of any future financings, if needed, will depend upon
maintenance of adequate earnings, regulatory approval, prevailing market conditions, and other
factors. Mississippi Power is considering other sources of funding for storm-recovery costs. See
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of
Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At September&nbsp;30, 2006, Mississippi Power&#146;s current liabilities exceeded current assets
primarily as a result of obligations incurred as a result of Hurricane Katrina, as well as the
continued use of short-term debt as a funding source to meet cash needs, which can fluctuate
significantly due to the seasonality of the business. To meet short-term cash needs and
contingencies, Mississippi Power had at September&nbsp;30, 2006 approximately $25.6&nbsp;million of cash and
cash equivalents and $275.5&nbsp;million of unused committed credit arrangements with banks. Of these
facilities, $20.5&nbsp;million expire in 2006, $80&nbsp;million expire in 2007, and $175&nbsp;million expire in
2008. See Note 6 to the financial statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Bank Credit Arrangements&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K
for additional information. Approximately $38&nbsp;million of these credit arrangements contain
provisions allowing two-year term loans executable at expiration and $15&nbsp;million contain provisions
allowing
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->102<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
