<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>MISSISSIPPI POWER COMPANY</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">one-year term loans executable at expiration. Mississippi Power expects to renew its credit
facilities, as needed, prior to expiration. The credit arrangements provide liquidity support to
Mississippi Power&#146;s obligations with respect to variable rate pollution control bonds and
commercial paper. A portion of these facilities may be used to fund or provide liquidity support
for commercial paper issuances to fund costs on an interim basis related to Hurricane Katrina. At
September&nbsp;30, 2006, Mississippi Power had $135.4&nbsp;million in commercial paper, $150&nbsp;million in bank
notes, and no extendible commercial notes outstanding. Management believes that the need for
working capital can be adequately met by utilizing commercial paper programs and lines of credit
without maintaining large cash balances.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Off-Balance Sheet Financing Arrangements</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Off-Balance Sheet
Financing Arrangements&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 7 to the financial statements of
Mississippi Power under &#147;Operating Leases&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information related to
Mississippi Power&#146;s lease of a combined cycle generating facility at Plant Daniel.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in
payment schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. However, Mississippi
Power, along with all members of the Southern Company power pool, is party to certain derivative
agreements that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a credit rating
change to below investment grade for Alabama Power and/or Georgia Power. These agreements are
primarily for natural gas price risk management activities. At September&nbsp;30, 2006, Mississippi
Power&#146;s total exposure to these types of agreements was approximately $25&nbsp;million.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed
materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2005 reporting period.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to cost-based rate regulation, Mississippi Power has limited exposure to market volatility
in interest rates, commodity fuel prices, and prices of electricity. To mitigate residual risks
relative to movements in electricity prices, Mississippi Power enters into physical fixed-price
contracts for the purchase and sale of electricity through the wholesale electricity market.
Mississippi Power has also implemented retail fuel hedging programs at the instruction of the
Mississippi PSC and wholesale fuel hedging programs under agreements with wholesale customers.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value of derivative, fuel, and energy contracts at September&nbsp;30, 2006 was as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unrealized gains and losses from mark-to-market adjustments on derivative contracts related to
Mississippi Power&#146;s fuel hedging programs are recorded as regulatory assets and liabilities.
Realized gains and losses from these programs are included in fuel expense and are recovered
through Mississippi Power&#146;s energy cost management clause. In addition, any unrealized gains and
losses on energy-related derivatives used to hedge anticipated purchases and sales are deferred in
other comprehensive income. Gains and losses on derivative contracts that are not designated as
hedges are recognized in the statements of income as incurred. These amounts were not material in
any period presented. At September&nbsp;30, 2006, the fair value gain/(loss) of derivative energy
contracts was reflected in the financial statements as follows:
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">

LIQUIDITY &#150; &#147;Market Price Risk&#148; of Mississippi Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Notes 1 and 6 to the financial
statements of Mississippi Power under &#147;Financial Instruments&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K and Note
(F)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mississippi Power did not issue or redeem any long-term securities in the first nine months of
2006. In addition to any financings that may be necessary to meet capital requirements,
contractual obligations, and storm restoration costs, Mississippi Power plans to continue, when
economically feasible, a program to retire higher-cost securities and replace these obligations
with lower-cost capital if market conditions permit.</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->104<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<A name="133"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 14pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY<BR>AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->105<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="134"></A>
</DIV>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="138"></A>
</DIV>
<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>

FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</DIV>



<DIV align="Center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">THIRD QUARTER 2006 vs. THIRD QUARTER 2005<BR>
AND<BR>
YEAR-TO-DATE 2006 vs. YEAR-TO-DATE 2005

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>OVERVIEW</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power constructs, owns, and manages Southern Company&#146;s competitive generation assets and
sells electricity at market-based rates in the southeastern United States wholesale market.
Southern Power continues to focus on executing its regional strategy in 2006 in the southeast, one
of the fastest growing regions of the country, including potential acquisition and/or expansion
opportunities. Southern Power continues to address questions at the federal regulatory level
relative to market power and affiliate transactions. See FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL <B>- </B>&#147;FERC
Matters&#148; herein for additional detail.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To evaluate operating results and to ensure Southern Power&#146;s ability to meet its contractual
commitments to customers, Southern Power focuses on several key performance indicators. These
indicators consist of plant availability, peak season equivalent forced outage rate (EFOR), and net
income. Plant availability shows the percentage of time during the year that Southern Power&#146;s
generating units are available to be called upon to generate (the higher the better), whereas the
EFOR more narrowly defines the hours during peak demand times when Southern Power&#146;s generating
units are not available due to forced outages (the lower the better). For additional information
on these indicators, see MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; OVERVIEW &#151; &#147;Key Performance
Indicators&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Earnings</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s net income for the third quarter 2006 was $45.9&nbsp;million compared to $39.2&nbsp;million
for the corresponding period of 2005. The increase in third quarter 2006 earnings of $6.6&nbsp;million,
or 16.9%, was primarily the result of revenues from new PPAs including a contract with Piedmont
Municipal Power Authority (PMPA), effective January&nbsp;1, 2006, and PPAs related to the acquisitions
of Plant DeSoto in June&nbsp;2006 and Plant Rowan in September&nbsp;2006. Also contributing to income was an
increase in short-term market energy sales available due to favorable regional weather conditions.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Power&#146;s net income for year-to-date 2006 was $97.6&nbsp;million compared to $87.5&nbsp;million
for the corresponding period of 2005. Year-to-date 2006 earnings were $10.1&nbsp;million, or 11.5%,
higher than year-to-date 2005 primarily as a result of revenues from new PPAs, including PMPA and
contracts
associated with newly acquired plants. For year-to-date 2006 changes, these acquisitions included Plant
Oleander in June&nbsp;2005, Plant DeSoto in June&nbsp;2006, and Plant Rowan in September&nbsp;2006. These factors
were partially offset by higher operating and maintenance expenses, as well as increased
depreciation expense.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->110<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant income statement items appropriate for discussion include the following:
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="52%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Sales for resale </I>- <I>affiliates and Sales for resale </I>- <I>non-affiliates</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, revenues related to sales for resale to non-affiliates increased
while revenues from sales for resale to affiliates decreased when compared to the corresponding
period in 2005. Revenues from sales for resale to non-affiliates increased $18.8&nbsp;million during
the period, primarily due to sales increases related to the new PMPA contract, short-term market
energy sales, and sales from Plant DeSoto, acquired in June&nbsp;2006, and Plant Rowan, acquired in
September&nbsp;2006. Revenues from sales for resale to affiliates decreased $16.2&nbsp;million during the
period, primarily due to reduced energy revenues due to lower natural gas prices. Reduced natural
gas prices also contributed to an increase in longer continuous use for Southern Power plants which
resulted in a decrease in revenues under the pricing structure of certain affiliate PPAs.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, revenues from sales for resale to non-affiliates increased $53.6
million and revenues from sales for resale to affiliates decreased $20.5&nbsp;million when compared to
the same period in 2005. The increase in revenues from sales for resale to non-affiliates was
primarily due to sales from Plant Oleander, short-term market energy, the new PMPA PPA, and
revenues from PPAs with Georgia electric membership cooperatives. The decrease in sales for resale
to affiliates was primarily due to lower natural gas prices resulting in reduced energy revenues.
Also contributing were reduced revenues as a result of greater continuous use as discussed above.
See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Power Sales Agreements&#148; of
Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K and FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Plant Acquisitions&#148; and
&#147;Power Sales Agreements&#148; herein for additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fuel expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, fuel expense decreased $19.2&nbsp;million when compared to the same
period in 2005 primarily due to a 63.6% decrease in the price of natural gas. Partially offsetting
this decrease was a 35% increase in generation at Plant Wansley and a 16% increase in generation at
Plant Dahlberg.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, fuel expense decreased $26.0&nbsp;million when compared to the same period
in 2005 primarily due to a 14.3% decrease in natural gas prices. This was partially offset by a
9.9% increase in generation at Plant Wansley. Existing PPAs generally provide that the purchasers
are responsible for substantially all of the fuel costs relating to energy delivered under the
PPAs; therefore, fuel expenses do not have a significant impact on net income.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Purchased power expense &#151; affiliates and Purchased power expense &#151; non-affiliates</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, total purchased power increased $3.2&nbsp;million and
$18.9&nbsp;million, respectively, when compared to the corresponding periods in 2005. This was
primarily due to increased purchases from lower cost energy resources from the Southern Company
Power Pool and from contracts with the City of Dalton and PMPA.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->111<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Other operations expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, other operations expense increased $2.4&nbsp;million when compared to
the corresponding period in 2005. This increase was primarily due to $1&nbsp;million of additional
administrative expense and $0.7&nbsp;million of operations expense related to newly acquired Plants
DeSoto and Rowan. Also contributing to the increase were transmission expenses related to the PMPA
PPA, which were $0.8&nbsp;million in the third quarter. The PMPA contract provides for recovery of
substantially all direct transmission costs; therefore, these expenses do not have a significant
impact on net income.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, other operations expense increased $10.2&nbsp;million when compared to the
corresponding period in 2005. This increase was primarily due to $6.2&nbsp;million of additional
administrative expense and $1.8&nbsp;million of operations expense related to Plants Oleander, DeSoto,
and Rowan. Also contributing to the increase were transmission expenses related to the PMPA PPA,
which were $1.8&nbsp;million for year-to-date 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Maintenance expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter and year-to-date 2006, maintenance expense increased $0.3&nbsp;million and
$3.5&nbsp;million, respectively, when compared to the corresponding periods in 2005, primarily due to
operations at Plants DeSoto and Rowan, as well as the timing of plant maintenance activities.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Depreciation and amortization expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter 2006, depreciation expense increased
$2.8&nbsp;million when compared to the corresponding period in 2005, primarily as a result of higher depreciation
rates from a new depreciation study adopted in March&nbsp;2006. The change in rates contributed an
additional $1.4&nbsp;million to the third quarter 2006 expense. New plant in service relating to Plants
DeSoto and Rowan, acquired in June&nbsp;2006 and September&nbsp;2006, respectively, also contributed $1.3
million to the third quarter increase.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For year-to-date 2006, depreciation expense increased $7.5&nbsp;million when compared to the
corresponding period in 2005, primarily as a result of a change in depreciation rates related to a
new depreciation study adopted in March&nbsp;2006. The change in rates contributed an additional $3.5
million in year-to-date 2006 expense. Depreciation related to new plant in service also
contributed an additional $3.9&nbsp;million to depreciation expense as Plants Oleander, DeSoto, and
Rowan were acquired in June&nbsp;2005, June&nbsp;2006, and September&nbsp;2006, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Income tax expense</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income tax expense increased $6.8&nbsp;million and $10.0&nbsp;million in the third quarter and
year-to-date 2006, respectively, when compared to the corresponding periods in 2005. This was primarily
due to higher taxable earnings. Also contributing was a higher state income tax rate in the State
of North Carolina.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The results of operations discussed above are not necessarily indicative of Southern Power&#146;s future
earnings potential. Several factors affect the opportunities, challenges, and risks of Southern
Power&#146;s competitive wholesale energy business. These factors include the ability to achieve sales
growth while containing costs. Another major factor is federal regulatory policy, which may impact
Southern Power&#146;s level of participation in this market. The level of future earnings depends on
numerous factors, especially regulatory matters, including those related to affiliate contracts,
sales, creditworthiness of customers, total generating capacity available in the Southeast, and the
successful remarketing of capacity as current contracts expire. For additional information
relating to these issues, see RISK FACTORS in Item&nbsp;1A and MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS -
FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->112<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FERC Matters</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS">  &#151; </FONT>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC Matters -
Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 2 to the financial statements of
Southern Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#151; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order adopting a new interim analysis for measuring generation
market power and a proceeding initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to assess Southern Company&#146;s
generation dominance within its retail service territory. Southern Power has authorization from
the FERC to sell power to non-affiliates, including short-term opportunity sales, at market-based
prices. Specific FERC approval must be obtained with respect to a market-based sale to an
affiliate. On February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company submitted additional information related to
generation dominance in its retail service territory. Any new market-based rate sales by any
subsidiary of Southern Company in its retail service territory entered into after February&nbsp;27, 2005
will be subject to refund to the level of the default cost-based rates, pending the outcome of the
proceeding. Such sales through May&nbsp;27, 2006, the end of the 15-month refund period, were
approximately $0.7&nbsp;million for Southern Power. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation
measures for entities that are found to have market power are ultimately applied, Southern Power
may be required to charge cost-based rates for certain wholesale sales in the Southern Company
retail service territory, which may be lower than negotiated market-based rates. The final outcome
of this matter will depend on the form in which the final methodology for assessing generation
market power and mitigation rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated an investigation to determine whether Southern
Company satisfies the other three parts of the FERC&#146;s market-based rate analysis: transmission
market power, barriers to entry, and affiliate abuse or reciprocal dealing. The FERC established a
new 15-month refund period related to this expanded investigation. Any new market-based rate sales
involving any Southern Company subsidiary will be subject to refund to the extent the FERC orders
lower rates as a result of this new investigation, with the refund period beginning July&nbsp;19, 2005.
The impact of such sales involving Southern Power through September&nbsp;30, 2006 is not expected to
exceed $4.4&nbsp;million, of which $0.6&nbsp;million relates to sales inside the retail service territory
discussed above. The FERC also directed that this expanded proceeding be held in abeyance pending
the outcome of the proceeding on the IIC discussed below. In its order in the IIC proceeding of
October&nbsp;5, 2006, pertaining to issues that overlap those in this proceeding, the FERC indicated
that it would issue an order in this expanded proceeding within 90&nbsp;days, seeking comment on the issues that may remain
appropriate for investigation as well as procedures for addressing those issues.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Power believes that there is no meritorious basis for this proceeding and is
vigorously defending itself in this matter. However, the final outcome of this matter, including
any remedies to be applied in the event of an adverse ruling in this proceeding, cannot now be
determined.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated a new proceeding to examine (1)&nbsp;the provisions of the IIC
among Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, Savannah Electric, Southern
Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of which the power pool of Southern Company is
operated, and, in particular, the propriety of the continued inclusion of Southern Power as a
party to the IIC, (2)&nbsp;whether any parties to the IIC have violated the FERC&#146;s standards of
conduct applicable to utility companies that are transmission providers, and (3)&nbsp;whether
Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->113<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">defining Southern Power as a &#147;system company&#148; rather than a &#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just and
reasonable. In connection with the formation of Southern Power, the FERC authorized Southern
Power&#146;s inclusion in the IIC in 2000. The FERC also previously approved Southern Company&#146;s code
of conduct. The FERC order directs that the ALJ who presided over a proceeding involving
approval of PPAs between Southern Power and Georgia Power and Savannah Electric be assigned to
preside over the hearing in this proceeding and that the testimony and exhibits presented in
that proceeding be preserved to the extent appropriate. Effective July&nbsp;19, 2005, revenues from
transactions under the IIC involving any Southern Company subsidiaries will be subject to refund
to the extent the FERC orders any changes to the IIC.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;11, 2006, Southern Company, Calpine Corporation, Coral Energy, and Dalton
Utilities filed a settlement offer that would resolve the proceeding, and does not require any
refunds. The ALJ certified the settlement to the FERC, which on October&nbsp;5, 2006 issued an order
accepting the settlement subject to Southern Company&#146;s agreement to accept certain modifications
to its terms. On October&nbsp;20, 2006, Southern Company notified the FERC that it accepted the
modifications. The modifications largely involve functional separation and information
restrictions related to marketing activities conducted on behalf of Southern Power<I>. </I>Southern
Company filed with the FERC on November&nbsp;6, 2006 an implementation plan to comply with
the modifications set forth in the order. The impact of the modifications is currently being
assessed but is not expected to be material. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS">  &#151; </FONT>FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;FERC Matters &#151; Intercompany Interchange
Contract&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 and Note 2 to the financial statements of Southern Power
under &#147;FERC Matters &#151; Intercompany Interchange Contract&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Franklin Unit 3 Construction Activities</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See Note 2 to the financial statements of Southern Power under &#147;Plant Franklin Unit 3 Construction
Project&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on the suspension of construction activities.
On May&nbsp;6, 2006, Southern Power signed a PPA with Progress Ventures, Inc. for 621 MW of capacity
from Plant Franklin. The PPA term is from 2009 through 2015. To provide this capacity, Southern
Power expects to complete construction of Franklin Unit 3 at a total cost of approximately $351
million, of which $176&nbsp;million had been spent as of September&nbsp;30, 2006. Construction is expected
to be complete in 2008.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Plant Acquisitions</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Effective June&nbsp;1, 2006, Southern Power acquired all of the outstanding membership interests of
DeSoto County Generating Company, LLC (DeSoto) from Progress Genco Ventures LLC, a subsidiary of
Progress Energy, Inc. The results of DeSoto&#146;s operations have been included in Southern Power&#146;s
consolidated financial statements since that date. Southern Power&#146;s acquisition of the membership
interests in DeSoto was pursuant to an agreement dated May&nbsp;8, 2006 for an aggregate purchase price
of $79.2&nbsp;million. DeSoto owns a dual-fired generating plant near Arcadia, Florida with a nameplate
capacity of 340 MW. The plant&#146;s capacity and associated energy is sold under PPAs with Florida
Power &#038; Light Company that expire in 2007.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective September&nbsp;1, 2006, Southern Power also acquired all of the outstanding membership
interests of Rowan County Power, LLC (Rowan) from the same subsidiary of Progress Energy, Inc.
Rowan owns a dual-fired generating plant near Salisbury, North Carolina with a nameplate capacity
of 985 MW. The purchase price was $328.8&nbsp;million. Through the acquisition, Southern Power assumed
PPAs with Duke Power and North Carolina Municipal Power Agency No.&nbsp;1 that expire at various times
through 2030. In addition, Southern Power entered into PPAs with Energy United Electric Membership
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->114<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Corporation for capacity and associated energy from Plant Rowan effective September&nbsp;2006 through
December&nbsp;2025. Substantially all of Plant Rowan&#146;s capacity is under contract from 2011 through
2025. See Note (L)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information
regarding these acquisitions.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Power Sales Agreements</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In May&nbsp;2006, Southern Power entered into a PPA with Progress Ventures, Inc. for 621 MW of annual
capacity from Plant Franklin. The PPA term is from early 2009 through December&nbsp;2015 with an option
to extend through 2020. This capacity is expected to be provided from Plant Franklin Unit 3. See
&#147;Franklin Unit 3 Construction Activities&#148; above for details on the restart of construction.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July&nbsp;2006, Southern Power entered into four PPAs with Energy United Electric Membership
Corporation. Under the PPAs, Southern Power will sell approximately 425 MW annually of wholesale
capacity from Plant Rowan and existing resources. Two of the PPAs are full requirements agreements
from September&nbsp;2006 through December&nbsp;2010 and from January&nbsp;2011 through December&nbsp;2025,
respectively. The remaining two PPAs are block purchases from Plant Rowan with terms beginning in
January&nbsp;2011 and extending through December&nbsp;2025.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In October&nbsp;2006, Southern Power entered into a PPA with Gulf Power, resulting from a
competitive request for proposals process. Southern Power will sell 300 MW annually of wholesale
capacity from existing resources. The contract term is June&nbsp;2009 through May&nbsp;2014. The agreement
is subject to approval by the Florida PSC and the FERC.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Matters</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Power Sales Agreements&#148; of
Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information on long-term PPAs. Southern
Power&#146;s PPAs with non-affiliated counterparties have provisions that require the posting of
collateral or an acceptable substitute guarantee in the event that the counterparty does not meet
certain rating or financial requirements. The PPAs are expected to provide Southern Power with a
stable source of revenue during their respective terms.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#151; &#147;Environmental Matters&#148;
of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for information on the development by federal and
state environmental regulatory agencies of additional control strategies for emission of air
pollution from industrial sources, including electric generating facilities. Compliance costs
related to current and future environmental laws and regulations could affect earnings if such
costs are not fully recovered. While Southern Power&#146;s PPAs generally contain provisions that
permit charging the counterparty with some of the new costs incurred as a result of changes in
environmental laws and regulations, the full impact of any such regulatory or legislative changes
cannot be determined at this time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Power is subject to certain claims and legal actions arising in the ordinary course
of business. In addition, Southern Power&#146;s business activities are subject to extensive
governmental regulation related to public health and the environment. Litigation over
environmental issues and claims of various types, including property damage, personal injury, and
citizen enforcement of environmental requirements such as opacity and other air quality standards,
has increased generally throughout the
United States. In particular, personal injury claims for damages caused by alleged exposure to
hazardous materials have become more frequent. The ultimate outcome of such potential litigation
against Southern
</DIV>

</DIV>

liabilities, if any, arising from any such current proceedings would have a material adverse effect
on Southern Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Note (B)&nbsp;to the Condensed Financial Statements herein for discussion of various other

earnings potential.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Application of Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates</B>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power prepares its financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States. Significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 to the
financial statements of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K. In the application of these
policies, certain estimates are made that may have a material impact on Southern Power&#146;s results of
operations and related disclosures. Different assumptions and measurements could produce estimates
that are significantly different from those recorded in the financial statements. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS<FONT style="font-variant: SMALL-CAPS"> &#151; </FONT>ACCOUNTING POLICIES &#151; &#147;Application of Critical Accounting
Policies and Estimates&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a complete discussion of
Southern Power&#146;s critical accounting policies and estimates related to revenue recognition and
asset impairments.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>New Accounting Standards</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Income Taxes</I>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In July&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued Interpretation No.&nbsp;48 (FIN 48), &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income
Taxes.&#148; This interpretation requires that tax benefits must be &#147;more likely than not&#148; of being
sustained in order to be recognized. The provisions of FIN 48 must be applied to all tax positions
beginning January&nbsp;1, 2007. Southern Power is currently assessing the impact of FIN 48. The impact
on Southern Power&#146;s financial statements has not yet been determined.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Fair Value Measurement</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The FASB issued FASB Statement No.&nbsp;157 (SFAS No.&nbsp;157), &#147;Fair Value Measurements&#148; in September&nbsp;2006.
This standard provides guidance on how to measure fair value where it is permitted or required
under other accounting pronouncements. SFAS No.&nbsp;157 also requires additional disclosures about
fair value measurements. Southern Power will adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;157 on January&nbsp;1, 2008 and is
currently assessing the impact of this standard.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Guidance on Considering the Materiality of Misstatements</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In September&nbsp;2006, the SEC issued Staff Accounting Bulletin No.&nbsp;108 (SAB 108), &#147;Considering the
Effects of Prior Year Misstatements when Quantifying Misstatements in Current Year Financial
Statements.&#148; SAB 108 addresses how the effects of prior year uncorrected misstatements should be
considered when quantifying misstatements in current year financial statements. SAB 108 requires
companies to quantify misstatements using both a balance sheet and an income statement approach and
to evaluate whether either approach results in quantifying an error that is material in light of
relevant
quantitative and qualitative factors. When the effect of initial adoption is material, companies
will record the effect as a cumulative effect adjustment to beginning of year retained earnings.
The provisions of
</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->116<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">SAB 108 are effective for Southern Power for the year ending December&nbsp;31, 2006. The adoption of SAB
108 is not expected to have a material impact on Southern Power&#146;s financial statements.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Overview</B>

</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power&#146;s financial condition remained stable at September&nbsp;30, 2006. Major changes in
Southern Power&#146;s financial condition for the nine months ended September&nbsp;30, 2006 included the
payment of $58.3&nbsp;million in dividends to Southern Company, the completion of the sale of Cherokee
Falls Development of South Carolina LLC and all of its assets at cost to Southern Company&#146;s nuclear
development affiliate, and the acquisition of Plants DeSoto and Rowan in June and September&nbsp;2006,
respectively, which contributed an additional $398&nbsp;million of utility plant. These acquisitions
were financed with the issuance of additional short-term commercial paper and a capital
contribution of $105&nbsp;million from Southern Company.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Capital Requirements and Contractual Obligations</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Capital
Requirements and Contractual Obligations&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for a
description of Southern Power&#146;s capital requirements for its construction program, maturing debt,
purchase commitments, and long-term service agreements. Approximately $1.2&nbsp;million will be
required by September&nbsp;30, 2007 for maturities of long-term debt.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Sources of Capital</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power may use operating cash flows, external funds, or capital contributions from Southern
Company to finance any new projects, acquisitions, and ongoing capital requirements. Southern Power
expects to generate external funds from commercial paper, the issuance of unsecured senior debt,
preferred equity securities, or the utilization of credit arrangements from banks. See
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of
Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At September&nbsp;30, 2006, Southern Power&#146;s current liabilities exceeded current assets due to the
use of short-term debt as a funding source to finance the Plant Oleander, Plant DeSoto, and Plant
Rowan acquisitions and for general corporate needs. At September&nbsp;30, 2006, Southern Power had
approximately $36.9&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents to meet short-term cash needs and
contingencies. To insure liquidity and capital resource requirements, Southern Power has a $400
million committed credit facility with banks that expires in 2011. Proceeds from borrowings under
this arrangement may be used for working capital and general corporate purposes as well as
liquidity support for Southern Power&#146;s commercial paper program. At September&nbsp;30, 2006, Southern
Power had approximately $327&nbsp;million of commercial paper outstanding. Amounts drawn under the
commercial paper program may be used to finance acquisition and construction costs related to
electric generating facilities and for general corporate purposes. See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND
ANALYSIS &#151; FINANCIAL CONDITION AND LIQUIDITY &#151; &#147;Sources of Capital&#148; of Southern Power in Item&nbsp;7 of
the Form 10-K for additional information.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->117<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>SOUTHERN POWER COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARY COMPANIES</B><BR>
MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR>
FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Credit Rating Risk</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power does not have any credit arrangements that would require material changes in payment
schedules or terminations as a result of a credit rating downgrade. There are certain contracts
that could require collateral, but not accelerated payment, in the event of a credit rating change
to BBB and Baa2 or to BBB- or Baa3 or below. Generally, collateral may be provided with a
Southern Company guaranty, letter of credit, or cash. These contracts are primarily for physical
electricity purchases and sales. At September&nbsp;30, 2006, the maximum potential collateral
requirements at a BBB and Baa2 rating were approximately $9&nbsp;million and at a BBB- or Baa3 rating
were approximately $250&nbsp;million. The maximum potential collateral requirements at a rating below
BBB- or Baa3 were approximately $389&nbsp;million. In addition,
through the acquisition of Plant Rowan,
Southern Power assumed a PPA with Duke Power Company LLC that could require collateral, but not
accelerated payment, in the event of a credit rating change to below BBB- or Baa3. The amount of
collateral required would depend upon actual losses, if any, resulting from a credit downgrade,
limited to Southern Power&#146;s remaining obligations under the contract. See Note (L)&nbsp;to the
Condensed Financial Statements herein for additional information regarding the acquisition.
Southern Power, along with all members of the Southern Company power pool, is also party to certain
derivative agreements that could require collateral and/or accelerated payment in the event of a
credit rating change to below investment grade for Alabama Power and/or Georgia Power. These
agreements are primarily for natural gas price risk management activities. At September&nbsp;30, 2006,
Southern Power&#146;s total exposure to these types of agreements was approximately $25&nbsp;million.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Market Price Risk</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power is exposed to market risks, including changes in interest rates, certain
energy-related commodity prices, and, occasionally, currency exchange rates. To manage the
volatility attributable to these exposures, Southern Power nets the exposures to take advantage of
natural offsets and enters into various derivative transactions for the remaining exposures
pursuant to Southern Power&#146;s policies in areas such as counterparty exposure and hedging practices.
Southern Power&#146;s policy is that derivatives are to be used primarily for hedging purposes.
Derivative positions are monitored using techniques that include market valuation and sensitivity
analysis.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Power&#146;s market risk exposures relative to interest rate changes have not changed
materially compared with the December&nbsp;31, 2005 reporting period. In addition, Southern Power is
not aware of any facts or circumstances that would significantly affect such exposures in the near
term.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Because energy from Southern Power&#146;s generating facilities is primarily sold under long-term
PPAs with tolling agreements and provisions shifting substantially all of the responsibility for
fuel cost to the purchasers, Southern Power&#146;s exposure to market volatility in commodity fuel
prices and prices of electricity is limited. To mitigate residual risks in those areas, Southern
Power enters into fixed-price contracts for the sale of electricity.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value of changes in derivative energy contracts at September&nbsp;30, 2006 was as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Unrealized pre-tax gains and losses on electric contracts used to hedge anticipated sales, and gas
contracts used to hedge anticipated purchases and sales, are deferred in Other Comprehensive
Income. Gains and losses on derivative contracts that are not designated as hedges are recognized
in the statements of income as incurred.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financing Activities</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Southern Power did not issue or redeem any long-term securities during the nine months ended
September&nbsp;30, 2006. In the second quarter of 2006, Southern Power entered into a derivative
transaction to hedge the interest rate risk of a planned future financing. The derivative has a
total notional amount of $200&nbsp;million and will be terminated at the time of the future financing,
with any resulting gain or loss amortized over a 10-year period. For further details, see Note (F)
to the Condensed Financial Statements herein.
</DIV>

    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">(A)</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The condensed quarterly financial statements of the registrants included herein have
been prepared by each registrant, without audit, pursuant to the rules and regulations of
the SEC. The condensed balance sheets as of December&nbsp;31, 2005 have been derived from the
audited financial statements. In the opinion of each registrant&#146;s management, the
information regarding such registrant furnished herein reflects all adjustments necessary
to present fairly the results of operations for the periods ended September&nbsp;30, 2006 and
2005. Certain information and footnote disclosures normally included in financial
statements prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the
United States have been condensed or omitted pursuant to such rules and regulations,
although each registrant believes that the disclosures regarding such registrant are
adequate to make the information presented not misleading. Disclosure which would
substantially duplicate the disclosure in the Form 10-K and details which have not changed
significantly in amount or composition since the filing of the Form 10-K are omitted from
this Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q. Therefore, these condensed financial statements should
be read in conjunction with the financial statements and the notes thereto included in the
Form 10-K. Certain prior period amounts have been reclassified to conform to current
period presentation. Due to seasonal variations in the demand for energy, operating
results for the periods presented do not necessarily indicate operating results for the
entire year.</TD>
</TR>

    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD><U>NEW SOURCE REVIEW ACTIONS</U></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD><I>New Source Review Litigation</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS &#150; FUTURE EARNINGS POTENTIAL &#150; &#147;Environmental
Matters &#150; New Source Review Actions&#148; of Southern Company and Alabama Power in Item&nbsp;7 and
Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company and Alabama Power under
&#147;Environmental Matters &#150; New Source Review Actions&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for
additional information regarding a civil action brought by the EPA alleging that Alabama
Power had violated the NSR provisions of the Clean Air Act and related state laws with
respect to certain of its coal-fired generating facilities. On June&nbsp;19, 2006, the U.S.
District Court for the Northern District of Alabama entered a consent decree between Alabama
Power and the EPA, resolving alleged NSR violations at Plant Miller. The consent decree
required Alabama Power to pay $100,000 to resolve the government&#146;s claim for a civil penalty
and donate $4.9&nbsp;million of sulfur dioxide emission allowances to a nonprofit charitable
organization. As a result, Alabama Power has recognized $5&nbsp;million in other income
(expense), net related to the consent decree. The consent decree also formalizes specific
emissions reductions to be accomplished by Alabama Power, consistent with other Clean Air
Act programs that require emissions reductions. On August&nbsp;14, 2006, the district court
granted Alabama Power&#146;s motion for summary judgment and entered a final judgment in favor of
Alabama Power on the EPA&#146;s claims related to Plants Barry, Gaston, Gorgas, and Greene
County, based on the district court&#146;s previous ruling regarding the correct legal tests and
stipulations entered between the parties. The plaintiffs have appealed this decision to the
U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. The final resolution of</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->121<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

    <TD>these claims is dependent on these appeals and possible further court action and, therefore,
cannot be determined at this time.</TD>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD><I>New Source Review Reform Rules</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>On March&nbsp;17, 2006, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit vacated
the EPA&#146;s October&nbsp;2003 proposed rule which sought to clarify the scope of the existing
Routine Maintenance, Repair, and Replacement Exclusion. Because this rule was not yet in
effect, the court&#146;s ruling is not anticipated to have any impact on Southern Company or its
subsidiaries. In September&nbsp;2006, the EPA also proposed additional rules intended to clarify
the test for determining when an emissions increase subject to the NSR permitting
requirements has occurred. The potential impact of these proposed rules will depend on the
adoption of final rules by the EPA.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><U>PLANT WANSLEY ENVIRONMENTAL LITIGATION</U></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>On March&nbsp;30, 2006, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit ruled in favor of
Georgia Power on its appeal and reversed the district court&#146;s order regarding certain
alleged opacity violations at Plant Wansley. The court of appeals remanded the case to the
U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia for further proceedings consistent
with its decision. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot now be determined. See Note
3 to the financial statements of Southern Company and Georgia Power under &#147;Environmental
Matters &#151; Plant Wansley Environmental Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional
information.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><U>BIRMINGHAM AREA EIGHT-HOUR OZONE ATTAINMENT REDESIGNATION </U></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>On May&nbsp;12, 2006, the EPA published a final rule approving the State of Alabama&#146;s request to
redesignate the Birmingham eight-hour ozone nonattainment area to attainment under the
standard. The EPA also approved a revision to the Alabama state implementation plan,
containing a maintenance plan to ensure the area&#146;s continued compliance with the standard
and to address any future exceedances of the standard. The EPA&#146;s redesignation
determination became effective on June&nbsp;12, 2006.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><U>MIRANT MATTERS</U></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Mirant was an energy company with businesses that included independent power projects and
energy trading and risk management companies in the U.S. and selected other countries. It
was a wholly-owned subsidiary of Southern Company until its initial public offering in
October&nbsp;2000. In April&nbsp;2001, Southern Company completed a spin-off to its shareholders of
its remaining ownership, and Mirant became an independent corporate entity. In July&nbsp;2003,
Mirant filed for voluntary reorganization under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the Bankruptcy Code. See Note
3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Mirant Matters &#150; Mirant Bankruptcy&#148;
in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding Southern Company&#146;s contingent
liabilities associated with Mirant, including guarantees of contractual commitments,
litigation, and joint and several liabilities in connection with the consolidated federal
income tax return.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="1%"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD><I>Mirant Bankruptcy Litigation</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Mirant Matters &#150; Mirant
Bankruptcy Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding the complaint
filed in June&nbsp;2005 against Southern Company alleging fraudulent activities and payments of
illegal dividends prior to the spin-off. In May&nbsp;2006, Southern Company filed a motion for
summary judgment on all claims in the case. The ultimate outcome of this matter cannot be
determined at this time.</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt"><TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD><I>Mirant Securities Litigation</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Mirant Matters &#150; Mirant
Securities Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information regarding a class action
lawsuit that several Mirant shareholders (plaintiffs)&nbsp;originally filed against Mirant and
certain Mirant officers in May&nbsp;2002. In November&nbsp;2002, Southern Company, certain former and
current senior officers of Southern Company, and 12 underwriters of Mirant&#146;s initial public offering were added as defendants. In March
2006, the plaintiffs filed a Motion for Reconsideration requesting that the court vacate
that portion of its July&nbsp;2003 order dismissing the plaintiffs&#146; claims based upon Mirant&#146;s
alleged improper energy trading and marketing activities involving the California energy
market. Southern Company and the other defendants have opposed the plaintiffs&#146; motion. The
plaintiffs have also stated that they intend to request that the court grant leave for them
to amend the complaint to add allegations based upon claims asserted against Southern
Company in the Mirant bankruptcy litigation. See Note 3 to the financial statements of
Southern Company under &#147;Mirant Matters &#150; Mirant Bankruptcy Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form
10-K for additional information. The ultimate outcome of these matters cannot be determined
at this time.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD><I>Southern Company Employee Savings Plan Litigation</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company under &#147;Mirant Matters &#150; Southern
Company Employee Savings Plan Litigation&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information related
to the class action complaint filed under ERISA in June&nbsp;2004, and amended in December&nbsp;2004
and November&nbsp;2005, on behalf of a purported class of participants in or beneficiaries of The
Southern Company Employee Savings Plan at any time since April&nbsp;2, 2001 and whose plan
accounts included investments in Mirant common stock. In April&nbsp;2006, the U.S. District Court
for the Northern District of Georgia granted summary judgment in favor of Southern Company
and all individually named defendants in the case. The plaintiff has filed an appeal of the
ruling. The final outcome of this matter cannot be determined at this time.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><U>FERC MATTERS </U></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD><I>Market-Based Rate Authority</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>See Note 3 to the financial statements of Southern Company, Alabama Power, Georgia Power,
Gulf Power, and Mississippi Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate Authority&#148; and
Note 2 to the financial statements of Southern Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Market-Based Rate
Authority&#148; in Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for information on the FERC&#146;s April&nbsp;2004 order
adopting a new interim analysis for measuring generation market power and a proceeding
initiated by the FERC in December&nbsp;2004 to assess Southern Company&#146;s generation dominance
within its retail service territory. Each of the retail operating companies and Southern
Power has authorization from the FERC to sell power to non-affiliates, including short-term
opportunity sales, at market-based prices. Specific FERC approval must be obtained with
respect to a market-based sale to an affiliate. On February&nbsp;15, 2005, Southern Company
submitted additional information related to generation dominance in its retail service
territory. Any new market-based rate sales by any subsidiary of Southern Company in its
retail service territory entered into after February&nbsp;27, 2005 will be subject to refund to
the level of the default cost-based rates, pending the outcome of the proceeding. Such
sales through May&nbsp;27, 2006, the end of the 15-month refund period, were approximately $19.7
million for the Southern Company system. In the event that the FERC&#146;s default mitigation
measures for entities that are found to have market power are ultimately applied, the retail
operating companies and Southern Power may be required to charge cost-based rates for
certain wholesale sales in the Southern Company retail service territory, which may be lower
than negotiated market-based rates. The final outcome of this matter will depend on the
form in which the final methodology for assessing generation market power and mitigation
rules may be ultimately adopted and cannot be determined at this time.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->123<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt"><TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>In addition, in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated an investigation to determine whether Southern
Company satisfies the other three parts of the FERC&#146;s market-based rate analysis:
transmission market power, barriers to entry, and affiliate abuse or reciprocal dealing.
The FERC established a new 15-month refund period related to this expanded investigation.
Any new market-based rate sales involving any Southern Company subsidiary will be subject to
refund to the extent the FERC orders lower rates as a result of this new investigation, with
the refund period beginning July&nbsp;19, 2005. The impact of all such sales through September
30, 2006 is not expected to exceed $54.2&nbsp;million, of which $15.5&nbsp;million relates to sales
inside the retail service territory discussed above. The FERC also directed that this
expanded proceeding be held in abeyance pending the outcome of the proceeding on the IIC
discussed below. In its order in the IIC proceeding of October&nbsp;5, 2006, pertaining to
issues that overlap those in this proceeding, the FERC indicated that it would issue an
order in this expanded proceeding within 90&nbsp;days, seeking comment on the issues that may remain appropriate for
investigation as well as procedures for addressing those issues.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD>Southern Company and its subsidiaries believe that there is no meritorious basis for this
proceeding and are vigorously defending themselves in this matter. However, the final
outcome of this matter, including any remedies to be applied in the event of an adverse
ruling in this proceeding, cannot now be determined.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><I>&nbsp;</I></TD>
    <TD><I>Intercompany Interchange Contract</I></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Also in May&nbsp;2005, the FERC initiated a new proceeding to examine (1)&nbsp;the provisions of the
IIC among Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, Mississippi Power, Savannah Electric,
Southern Power, and SCS, as agent, under the terms of which the power pool of Southern
Company is operated, and, in particular, the propriety of the continued inclusion of
Southern Power as a party to the IIC, (2)&nbsp;whether any parties to the IIC have violated the
FERC&#146;s standards of conduct applicable to utility companies that are transmission providers,
and (3)&nbsp;whether Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct defining Southern Power as a &#147;system
company&#148; rather than a &#147;marketing affiliate&#148; is just and reasonable. In connection with the
formation of Southern Power, the FERC authorized Southern Power&#146;s inclusion in the IIC in
2000. The FERC also previously approved Southern Company&#146;s code of conduct. The FERC order
directs that the ALJ who presided over a proceeding involving approval of PPAs between
Southern Power and Georgia Power and Savannah Electric be assigned to preside over the
hearing in this proceeding and that the testimony and exhibits presented in that proceeding
be preserved to the extent appropriate. Effective July&nbsp;19, 2005, revenues from transactions
under the IIC involving any Southern Company subsidiaries will be subject to refund to the
extent the FERC orders any changes to the IIC.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>On April&nbsp;11, 2006, Southern Company, Calpine Corporation, Coral Energy, and Dalton Utilities
filed a settlement offer that would resolve the proceeding, and does not require any
refunds. The ALJ certified the settlement to the FERC, which on October&nbsp;5, 2006 issued an
order accepting the settlement subject to Southern Company&#146;s agreement to accept certain
modifications to its terms. On October&nbsp;20, 2006, Southern Company notified the FERC that it
accepted the modifications. The modifications largely involve functional separation and
information restrictions related to marketing activities conducted on behalf of Southern
Power. Southern Company filed with the FERC on November&nbsp;6, 2006 an implementation
plan to comply with the modifications set forth in the order. The
impact of the modifications is currently being
assessed but is not expected to be material. See Note 3 to the financial
statements of Southern Company, Alabama Power, Georgia Power, Gulf Power, and Mississippi
Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Intercompany Interchange Contract&#148; and Note 2 to the financial
statements of Southern Power under &#147;FERC Matters &#150; Intercompany Interchange Contract&#148; in
Item&nbsp;8 of the Form 10-K for additional information.</TD>
</TR>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE CONDENSED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS: (Continued)</B>
